Chapter 2 The Maroczy Bind The Maroczy Bind is one of the oldest Sicilian set-ups. I have selected six games for this chapter to explain what I consider to be the important aspects (strategic points) of this complex opening. Let's start with the 'Classical Maroczy Bind', examining positions that are favourable for Black and those that are favourable for White. In the first diagram we have a position Black is happy to achieve. The first important aspect is that Black's knight is safely placed on the c5-outpost; it will take White quite some time to conveniently hit it with b3-b4. Black's pieces are well coordinated and ready to take advantage of the mobile pawn structure, creating strong counterplay by pushing ...f5. Black can easily take over the initiative in such a position. In the second diagram we have a position White is happy to get. Black's knight is stuck on e6, White controls the c5-square (making it very difficult for Black to regroup), White has a space advantage and easy play while Black struggles to create counterplay. Our first two games illustrate the above-mentioned aspects very well. A straight attack for White Game 8 Bent Larsen Tigran Petrosian Santa Monica 1966

1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 g6 5.Be3 Bg7 6.c4 Nf6 7.Nc3 Ng4 8.Qxg4

Nxd4 9.Qd1 Ne6 10.Qd2 d6 11.Be2 Bd7 12.O-O O-O

13.Rad1

By developing the Ra1 to d1, White aims for a strategy combining a kingside attack with space dominance. Just like in the next game, Keres-Petrosian, the question whether Black is able to secure the c5-outpost for his knight plays a very important role here! An immediate kingside attacking idea has also been tried at top level: 13.f4 Bc6

14.f5 (on 14.Bf3 Black can choose: 14...Nc5 (14...Qa5 is a reasonable alternative)

and now White can opt for a pawn sacrifice with 15.b4!? Bxc3 16.Qxc3 Nxe4 with sharp play) 14...Nc5 15.Bf3. Black has to secure his knight's outpost: 15...a5! 16.Bh6 (Black's king is safe here - White will not get anything close to a Dragon attack) 16...Qb6 17.Bxg7 Kxg7

18.Kh1 f6 and Black had a good position and went on to win in Spassky-Savon,

Moscow 1973. White can certainly consider the immediate 13.b4 a5 14.a3, to control c5, when Black has no dynamic follow-up. For 13.Rac1 see the next game, Keres-Petrosian.

13...Bc6

Petrosian probably did not play 13...a5 because he was worried about White starting an attack with 14.f4 Bc6 15.Bf3 Nc5 analysis diagram

16.e5! Bxf3 17.Rxf3 b6 and now White can afford the violent 18.f5!. The position

opens up and White has a strong attack: 18...Bxe5 (also 18...dxe5 19.Qe1 Qe8

20.Nd5 will not end well for Black) 19.Bd4.

14.Nd5

An easy way for White to get a clear advantage here is to immediately deprive Black from the c5-outpost by playing 14.b4!. Black is doomed to passive defence; his knight on e6 is clumsy here. Trying to conquer c5 for his knight with 14...a5? leads to a disaster after the simple 15.b5 Bd7 16.Na4 and in a higher sense White has a winning advantage. It is interesting that two years prior, Bent Larsen played the same position as Black (!!), getting a good game and winning in the end. His opponent did not go for 14.b4!; it would be interesting to know why, playing White two years later, Bent did not go for 14.b4! here and also why Petrosian did not copy Larsen's play - for psychological reasons?

14...Re8

In the mentioned game, Larsen immediately secured the c5-outpost here with

14...Nc5! 15.f3 a5.

Black's situation improved further as White now made the wrong trade: 16.Bd4? when Larsen showed an instructive strategic plan: 16...Bxd4+ 17.Qxd4 e5!. Though the engines give zeros, in human play Black has the better chances in my opinion. White's Be2, locked up by its own pawns, is inferior to Black's excellently placed knight: 18.Qd2

18...Ne6 (Black could have opted for a good strategic trade with 18...Bxd5 with an

excellent position after 19.Qxd5 Ra6) 19.Ne3 Qb6. Black had a pleasant position and went on to win in Porat-Larsen, Amsterdam 1964. In our game, White starts immediate kingside action.

15.f4

White would have obtained a clear advantage with 15.b4!. Black's knight is deprived of the square c5 while the f5 pawn push is coming, with an attack.

15...Nc7?

This passive idea certainly does not help Black. Most likely Petrosian rejected 15...Nc5 because he did not like 16.e5, but still... for better or worse, this was the decision Black had to take here. It's good to know that after 16.Bf3 Black has an equalizing tactical motif that is useful to remember:

16...Nxe4! 17.Bxe4 e6=.

16.f5! Na6

Black is busy with his knight pirouette, achieving nothing. White probably felt the time was right to move to the execution phase and went for the direct:

17.Bg4

Simple 17.b4! was (in a higher sense) leading to a winning advantage. Black does not have the way to activate his knight. In reality White is a piece up on the kingside and will crush Black in attack!

17...Nc5!

Now Black is (very much) back in the game.

18.fxg6 hxg6 19.Qf2

Probably stronger was 19.Bxc5 dxc5 20.Qf4 Rf8 analysis diagram

21.e5! (note that the queen win 21.Nf6+ exf6 22.Rxd8 Raxd8 only improves Black's

position) 21...Bxd5 22.cxd5 Qb6. We have a position with opposite-coloured bishops, but White is the attacking side: 23.d6! exd6 24.e6! f5 25.e7 Rfe8 and White has an advantage, though the position is complicated. A logical run of play can be

26.Bf3! Bd4+! (26...Rxe7? 27.Bd5+ Kf8 28.Qg5 leads to a win for White) 27.Kh1

Rxe7 28.Qh6 Rh7! 29.Qxg6+ Kh8 30.Qxf5.

19...Rf8

20.Qh4 was possible here, but White makes a principled pawn sacrifice to continue

the attack:

20.e5!? Bxe5 21.Qh4 Bxd5 22.Rxd5

An interesting position. Many zeros for the computer engine... less easy for a human player!

22...Ne6

22...e6 is not an easy decision; after 23.Qxd8 Rfxd8 24.Rxe5 dxe5 25.Bxc5

analysis diagram to a human (at least to me) White's chances look better, however the engine holds this with active rook play: 25...Rac8!. After 22...Bf6 at first glance it looks like Black will be mated after 23.Rxf6 exf6

24.Bd4,

analysis diagram however Black has the defensive resource 24...Re8!! 25.Bxf6 Re1+ 26.Qxe1 (26.Kf2?? blunders into the prosaic 26...Ne4+) 26...Qxf6 with equality. The engine-type move 22...f5 (not likely to be played by a human) also appears to lead to equality: 23.Qg5 Bg7 24.Qxg6. analysis diagram Here Black needs to find 24...Rf6! (White has a winning attack in the event of

24...fxg4? 25.Rxf8+ Qxf8 26.Rf5 Qe8 27.Qxg4) 25.Qh5 e6! and after 26.Bxf5 (we

get a draw by perpetual check after 26.Bf3 exd5! 27.Bxd5+ Ne6 analysis diagram

28.g4! fxg4 29.Bxe6+ Rxe6 30.Qf7+ Kh8 31.Qh5+ Kg8 32.Qf7+ Kh8 and White

can play for a win but the position remains equal after 33.Qxe6 Qe8) 26...exd5

27.Qh7+ Kf8.

analysis diagram The position is very sharp. The zeroes evaluation by the engines does not mean much in human play here: 28.Bd4 Qe7! 29.cxd5 Qf7 30.b4, and the zeroes blinking on my computer tell me this position is 'dynamically balanced'.

23.Rf3

Now Black needs to be careful!

23...Bf6?

This runs into a nice finish. Black's king needed an escape square and it could have been created by 23...f5!

24.Rh3 Ng7!.

analysis diagram Now White has nothing better than to force a draw by perpetual check with 25.Qh7+ Kf7 26.Rh6 fxg4 27.Qxg6+ Kg8 28.Qh7+.

24.Qh6 Bg7

Bent Larsen must have felt great executing his next move!

25.Qxg6!!

Not a difficult sacrifice, but still a nice picture!

25...Nf4 26.Rxf4 fxg6 27.Be6+ Rf7 28.Rxf7 Kh8

29.Rg5

White has all the time in the world to give checkmate as Black's pieces are completely cut off and unable to help his poor monarch.

29...b5 30.Rg3 1-0

The importance of the c5-square Game 9 Paul Keres Tigran Petrosian Bled/Zagreb/Belgrade ct 1959

1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 g6 5.c4 Bg7 6.Be3 Nf6 7.Nc3 Ng4 8.Qxg4

Nxd4 9.Qd1 Ne6 10.Qd2 d6 11.Be2 Bd7 12.O-O O-O In my opinion, White has a clear advantage here if Black does not manage to secure c5-outpost for his knight. Without the knight on c5, Black is unable to create counterplay in these positions.

13.Rac1

White has a different set-up here starting with 13.Rad1 - see the previous game Larsen-Petrosian.

13...Bc6

An important moment!

14.Rfd1

This logical rook development is actually a mistake! Black now secures the c5- outpost for his knight and gets the type of position he was aiming for. Precise was 14.b4! with a clear advantage - more space, different plans. Black has no counterplay and is doomed to passivity: A) Fighting for the c5-square with 14...a5? leads to a disaster after 15.b5 Bd7

16.Na4. Black cannot coordinate his pieces at all, and White has a winning

advantage. For the reader to get an idea how bad Black's situation is, I will give the following line: 16.Rfd1 b6 17.Na4 Nc5 18.Nxc5 bxc5 19.a4. White has a passed pawn and more space and obviously should have an advantage here. The question is, how much of an advantage do you think Stockfish gives? The answer is almost plus three!; B) The pawn grab 14...Bxc3? 15.Qxc3 Bxe4 leads to suicide after 16.Bh6 Re8

17.Bg4 f5 18.Rfe1 and Black soon gets mated;

C) Probably Black has to opt for something like 14...b6. White has an easy advantage here and many good ways to continue; for example, 15.Nd5 or 15.h4.

14...Nc5 15.f3

Now Black secures his Nc5 outpost!

[diagram]
Suddenly Black has achieved his initial objective and he has a clear plan: b-pawn to b6, rook moves to d7 via a7, and then it will be time to push the kingside pawns: ...e6 followed by ...f5, with good play. White will be just playing around achieving nothing while Black will execute this plan. Checking with a computer engine may give you a wrong impression here. The engines are very happy with White's position, but in human play matters are not clear. Black wants to (and ultimately will) execute the mentioned plan, so what is White supposed to do here? Well, he has a couple of ideas to explore: a) prepare a3, followed by b4 and kick the Nc5 out; b) improve the Be2 by playing Bf1, g3 and Bh3; c) consider bold action pushing the g-pawn (g4).

16.b3 Qb6

Immediately starting with 16...b6 was the alternative.

17.Nb5

17.Nd5 was an alternative as after 17...Bxd5 (if Black plays 17...Qd8, White can

consider the above-mentioned plans) 18.cxd5 Qb4 the queens will be swapped and White will have an advantage in ending... the only question is how big. Other options are 17.Kh1 Qb4 18.Nd5 Bxd5 19.cxd5 Rfc8 or 17.Kf1.

17...Rfc8 18.Bf1

Black now decides to start the mentioned regrouping plan:

18...Qd8! 19.Qf2

19.g3 deserved attention.

19...Qe8 20.Nc3 b6 21.Rc2 Qf8 22.Qd2 Bd7 23.Nd5 Rab8 24.Bg5

The bold 24.g4!? was an option.

24...Re8 25.Re1

Let's suppose White wants to call it a day with 25.Nc7 Red8 26.Nd5 - well, Black can keep playing on with 26...f6 27.Be3 e6 28.Nf4 Bc6.

25...Rb7 26.Qf2 Bc6 27.Qh4

Black now executes the last phase of his regrouping plan:

27...f6! 28.Be3 e6! 29.Nc3

In the past 15 moves, Black has improved his position a lot while White's pieces are still more or less in the same positions(!). Black is ready for the ...f5 break, taking over the initiative. Note the importance of the stable Nc5 in all this!

29...Rd7

The immediate 29...f5 was certainly possible since Black pieces are well coordinated, e.g. 30.exf5 exf5 or 30...gxf5.

30.Bd4

Petrosian judges that the moment for the pawn break has come:

30...f5! 31.exf5 gxf5 32.Rd2

Black is happy to trade the dark-squared bishops.

32...Bxd4+ 33.Rxd4 Rg7 34.Kh1 Rg6 35.Rd2

Black has attacking potential here, his king is safer, the pawn on d6 is an 'academic weakness' and White's Bf1 is badly placed (dominated by the Nc5).

35...Rd8

Black could have played more directly with 35...Qg7 and ...e5 to follow.

36.Red1 Rd7 37.Qf2 Qd8 38.Qe3

After quite a lot of preparatory moves, Black decides to push his e-pawn.

38...e5

39...f4 looks unpleasant, so White decides to act:

39.f4

How should Black react? Uncharacteristically, Petrosian committed a serious strategic blunder:

[diagram]
Black kills his own bishop and kills his own attack. Petrosian must have overestimated the ...Nd3 jump ideas. Black had to increase the tension with 39...Qh4! when White's situation is not easy as after 40.Qf2 (40.fxe5 allows a strong attack: 40...Rh6 41.Qg1 dxe5 42.Rxd7 Nxd7; Black's king is safe, he has dangerous mobile pawns, the Bc6 is well placed while the Bf1 is doomed to passivity, e.g. 43.Nd5 f4 with ...Nc5, ...Rg6 to follow....Black is clearly better) Black can choose between grabbing a pawn and playing for the initiative with 40...Qh5. After 40...Qxf4 41.Qxf4 exf4 Black may have lousy pawns but one of them is extra. White faces an uphill struggle for a draw.

40.Ne2

As a result of Black's mistake, the situation has changed drastically. Black's d6- weakness is no longer 'academic' - now it is simply a weak pawn (just like f5)! White had to immediately target Black's pawn weaknesses with 40.Nb5! when he has a large advantage. The transaction 40...Bxb5 41.cxb5 does not help Black as the 'stupid' Bf1 goes to c4 and suddenly becomes a monster bishop, while the 'stable' Nc5 will have to leave its post as White will play a3 followed by b4.

40...Rdg7 41.Nd4 Bd7

Now finally White decides to chase away the Nc5 from its post:

42.a3 Qa8 43.Kg1

43.Nb5 led to White's advantage.

43...h5 44.Rb1 h4 45.Rbb2 Rg4 46.Rf2

White is ready to push 47.b4 with a clear advantage. Black needs a strong tactical resource here!

46...Qd8! 47.b4 Rg3!

To come up with this sacrifice, Petrosian needed to envision the pretty mating net that we are about to see. Keres takes a principled decision, accepting the sacrifice.

48.hxg3

White had an alternative in 48.Qe1 axb4 49.axb4 Nd3 50.Bxd3 Rxd3 51.Rfd2 with unclear play.

48...hxg3

The critical moment!

49.Rfd2?

In order to save His Majesty, White needed to return the material:

49.Rf3! Qh4 and now:

A) 50.Rxg3 Rxg3 51.Qe1 Na4. analysis diagram The position is equal but White needs a precise tactical defence: 52.Re2! Qxf4

53.Nxf5! Bxf5 54.Rf2! Qh4! (54...Qe3 leads to a drawish endgame: 55.Qxe3 Rxe3

56.Rxf5=)

analysis diagram White seems to have been tricked. 55.Rxf5?? loses the queen to 55...Rxg2 so Black is a piece up. But White saves the game using Black's weak king and hanging pieces: 55.Qd1! Qf6 (55...Nc3 keeps an extra piece but 56.Qxd6 holds). Now White gets his material back with equality by 56.Qxa4 or 56.Qd5+. B) The less human 50.Be2 also leads to approximate equality: 50...exf3 (the fancy

50...Qh2+ 51.Kf1 exf3 52.Nxf3 Ne4 does not create a real threat: White can calmly

take 53.bxa5! and Black struggles to find a good move as 53...bxa5?? blunders into the simple 54.Rb8+ Kh7 55.Nxh2 gxh2 56.Qh3+) 51.Nxf3 analysis diagram

51...Qh8! (Black wants to play 52...Rh7) 52.Qd4! Ne6 53.Qf6 Rh7 54.Qxh8+ Kxh8.

Now we get a few more trades, 55.Rd2 Nxf4 56.Bf1 Bc6 57.Rxd6 Bxf3 58.gxf3, leading to a probable draw. The 'computer move' 49.Be2 transposes after 49...Qh4 50.Rf3.

49...Qh4 50.Be2

White can no longer be saved as 50.Nf3 loses to 50...exf3 51.gxf3. analysis diagram Black is now only an exchange down while his mating attack continues... still, precision is needed: 51...Rh7! 52.Bg2 Re7! 53.Qd4 Re1+ 54.Bf1 and now the knight needs to join the party: 54...Ne6! 55.Qd5 (or 55.Qxd6 Nxf4). analysis diagram It would be wrong to think that any move wins, as only one move wins! 55...Be8

56.bxa5 Kg7! with 57...Nxf4 and the mating net is closed (56...Bf7? is wrong due to

the simple 57.Qxd6 and if 57...Nxf4 there will be 58.Qd8+).

50...Rh7 51.Kf1

And this instructive game concluded elegantly:

51...Qxf4+!! 0-1

The third game shows a strategically interesting plan of Bent Larsen's which is hardly used nowadays. It doesn't really work provided White reacts well. Larsen's dark-square domination Game 10 Anatoly Karpov 2710 Bent Larsen 2565 Brussels 1987

1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 g6 5.c4 Bg7 6.Be3 Nf6 7.Nc3 Ng4 8.Qxg4

Nxd4 9.Qd1 Ne6 In the 1980s, Larsen developed an interesting dark-square domination concept for Black here: keeping the king in the centre, starting with the early queen sortie to a5 and being ready to place his queen in the middle of the board e5-square. The concept had practical success against the world's very best players. However, if White knows what to aim for, Black can get into serious trouble. I will give four examples of top players (Karpov, Kramnik, Anand and Short) reacting as White. Anand was the only one whogot it right! Let's see and try to draw some conclusions.

10.Qd2

A game of Nigel Short playing White (vs Larsen) went 10.Rc1 Qa5 11.Be2 b6 12.0-

0 Bb7.

Already a critical position! What can be Black's problem here? Answer: his exposed queen. White should take action and harass the queen, at the price of a pawn if needed! One 'rule' is that a queen trade is okay for Black in this line. A) Instead of taking immediate action, White played a standard constructive move:

13.f3, and now Larsen went for his dark-square domination plan: 13...g5! 14.a3 (the

pawn sacrifice 14.Nd5 Bxb2 is not clear at all here) 14...Qe5. Due to Black's control of the dark squares, his queen is safe in the middle of the board. 15.Qd2. Black has already decided to keep his king in the centre and takes more space on the kingside: 15...h5! 16.Rfd1 d6. Not being able to disturb Black's queen, White takes the correct decision to push on the queenside: 17.b4 h4 18.Nd5 Kf8 19.Bf1 (probably best was to be consistent and continue 19.a4!) 19...Bc6. Black is controlling a lot of (dark) central squares, however now it's not easy to find a clever follow-up. It would be nice to make a couple of good trades - which is exactly what Nigel Short assists his opponent in doing: 20.Qd3 (the correct decision was 20.Qf2, preparing Rd2 followed by a4, and here we see another drawback of Black's concept: he has difficulty improving his position while White has a plan;

20.b5!? Bb7 21.a4 also deserves consideration) 20...Nf4. Now White makes the

wrong trades: 21.Nxf4? (it was not too late to change his mind and retreat with

21.Qd2) 21...gxf4. White now helps Black with another trade: 22.Bd4?! (22.Bf2)

22...Qxd4+ 23.Qxd4 Bxd4+ 24.Rxd4 Rh5.

Capablanca's rule was: 'Do not have pawns on the squares of your bishop' - have a look at White's bishop here! Black went on to win this ending in Short-Larsen, Brussels 1987; B) Much more to the point was 13.a3!. White wants to play 14.b4, embarrassing Black's queen, and Black is already in a rather unpleasant situation. B1) If 13...h5 (Black wants to play 14...g5, securing his queen on e5, but he won't get the time) 14.b4! Qxa3 15.Nd5 White has considerably more than just compensation - compare this to Anand-Ljubojevic later in the comments; B2) If 13...g5, trying to follow the same strategy Larsen did in the game, White has a pleasant choice between a temporary pawn sacrifice and using the fact that his f- pawn is still on f2 and play 14.Bg4. After 14.Nd5! Bxb2 Black's queen is badly placed: 15.Bd2 Qc5 16.Rc2 Be5 17.Bb4 and Black is in bad shape; B3) Whether he likes it or not, probably Black has to accept White's pawn sacrifice and part with his dark-squared bishop: 13...Bxc3 14.Rxc3 Bxe4 15.Re1. Black's queen is still exposed and he still has to castle, while White's pieces coordinate excellently... White has plenty of compensation here.

10...Qa5 11.Rc1 b6

This game was played in the same tournament as Short-Larsen, but this one was played first (played in the first round of the tournament). Karpov also takes a slow approach.

12.Be2

Vishy Anand, playing the same position ten years later (in a rapid game) did much better: 12.Bd3 Bb7 13.O-O. Ljubo knew Larsen's games and copied his plan: 13...g5. Anand takes the right approach: harass Black's queen and don't care if this involves a pawn sac: 14.a3! h5 15.b4!. Ljubo says: 'if I have to suffer, better to do so with a pawn up'. 15...Qxa3 (15...Qe5 was an option; however after 16.Nd5 White has a considerably better version of Short-Larsen; he will follow up with 17.a4 and open up the queenside, with a clear advantage. The position is similar to the game where White's a-pawn is still on the board) 16.Nd5 Qb2 17.Rc2 Qe5. Black has grabbed a pawn and his queen is, for the time being anyhow, safe in the centre. Black's problem? His queenside will collapse. 18.Ra2 h4 19.h3. Black understands that he won't be able to defend his queenside, so he hopes to create some threats to White's king: 19...Rg8 (if 19...Bxd5? 20.exd5 Nf4 21.Bxb6 Black starts losing material on the queenside without any threats to show for it) 20.Rd1 Bh8 (Black's threats are easy to stop) 21.Be2! Bc6 22.Bf3 Kf8. This was a rapid game, so even for a player of Anand's stature it's not easy to find the best execution. 23.b5! was White's quickest road to victory here (23.Qc2 was played in the game, White went on to win in Anand-Ljubojevic, Monaco 1997)

23...Bxd5 (23...Bb7 loses to 24.Nxe7) 24.exd5 and White wins on the queenside, e.g.

24...Nc5 25.Bxc5 bxc5 26.d6 Re8 27.Rxa7 etc.

12...Bb7 13.f3

Larsen comes up with his concept of gaining space on the kingside:

13...h5 14.O-O

In a rapid game, Kramnik took a cautious approach (not trying to harass Black's queen but trading the queens instead) and got nothing: 14.b3 h4 analysis diagram

15.Nd5?! (this only equalizes) 15...Qxd2+ 16.Kxd2 with a balanced game, later

drawn in Kramnik-Ljubojevic, Monaco rapid 1994. Larsen continues with his plan:

14...g5 15.Rfd1 d6

Now, similar to Kramnik, Karpov makes a wrong trade!

16.Nd5?

The queen trade helps Black here. Karpov probably overestimated his queenside pawn advance, but it would have had been considerably more efficient with queens on the board. Similar to Anand, White had to go for 16.a3! followed by b4, not being afraid to sacrifice a pawn in the process.

16...Qxd2 17.Rxd2

The position is now balanced. Black places his dark-squared bishop in the middle of the board and puts his kingside pawns on dark squares.

17...Be5 18.b4 Rc8 19.a4 h4 20.Bf1 f6 21.Ra2

White's dark-squared bishop is an important piece for his queenside activity, so it makes sense for Black to trade it.

21...Bd4! 22.Kf2 Kf7 23.a5

We now get trades, Black doing well in the ensuing N vs B positions.

23...Bxd5 24.exd5 Bxe3+ 25.Kxe3 Nf4

Black is happy with his N vs B here.

26.Kd2

White does not get a free hand to target Black's queenside.

26...Rc7! 27.axb6 axb6 28.Ra6

Black decides to play actively:

28...Rhc8

28...Rb8 was also good enough.

29.Rxb6 Nxd5 30.Rb5 Nf4 31.Ra5

Now Black improves his knight, targeting White's c4 weakness:

31...Ng6!

White has to be careful as Black is taking over.

32.c5 Ne5 33.Rc3 dxc5 34.bxc5 Rb8

Black's knight is strong while White's passer is not going anywhere.

35.Bb5 Rd8+ 36.Ke2

36...Nc6

Black decides to call it a day. He has a pleasant position here and could have continued without risk for a few more moves with 36...f5 or 36...e6 followed by ...f5, ...Kf6.

37.Bxc6 Rxc6 38.g3 Rd4=

Now we have a drawn rook ending.

39.Rb5 hxg3 40.hxg3 Rd5 41.g4 Rc7 42.Ke3 e6 43.Rc2 Ke7 44.Rc3 Kf7 45.Rc2

f5 46.gxf5 exf5 47.Kf2 Kg7 1⁄2-1⁄2 White plays a Dragon-type set-up A modern development in the Maroczy Bind (and not surprisingly, one the computer engines love!) is that White assumes the set-up on the kingside that is usually employed against the Dragon. Here White has his pawn on c4 instead of c2, making Black's counterplay more difficult. I have picked three modern games that show the problems Black might be facing. In Navara-Jakovenko we see that the g4-push can be dangerous for Black even when the queens are traded! In the other two games, Berdnarskiy-Vakhidov and Caruana- Carlsen, we see White's attacking potential although in both games White does not take advantage of it. In the early days of this variation, it was considered that White was able to force a great ending here by playing 12.Nd5. A) The ending is indeed bad for Black: 12...Qxd2+? 13.Kxd2. Black is forced to part with his bishop: 13...Bxd5 14.cxd5 Rfc8. White plays it very precisely:

15.Rxc8+ Rxc8.

White has a space advantage plus the bishop pair. He has a large advantage here and in a higher sense a technically won position. 13.g4!

Chapter 3 The Hedgehog Hedgehog-type positions can arise from different openings, but predominantly from the English Opening and the Sicilian Defence. This middlegame book is based on

1.e4 systems, so I will deal with Hedgehog-type positions arising from the Sicilian.

Hedgehog position usually arise from either of two well-known Sicilian Variations: the Taimanov and the Kan. The Hedgehog is a complex concept and things can easily go wrong for either side. I have selected eight sample games that show what to my mind are the pros & cons of these positions. My analysis of these games should improve the reader's understanding of the topic (and of the Hedgehog in practical play!). After reading this book, the reader will understand that in my personal opinion, Hedgehog positions arising from the Kan Variation are considerably more dangerous for Black. That said, many great players, including Anatoly Karpov, have opted (as White) to face the Hedgehog set-up in the Taimanov throughout their careers. In Hedgehog positions arising from the Taimanov Variation, I do not like White's knight on the a3-square - it definitely needs to be improved. Diagrams 1 and 2 show White taking action with a Scheveningen-type pawn storm while his knight is still stranded on a3. The Scheveningen pawn storm White has just pushed g4, believing that the Scheveningen-type pawn storm will work even with his knight still on a3. My Stockfish evaluates this diagrammed position as around zero... so it might work - certainly in practical play. However, this concept is rather risky for White as he may simply be 'missing a piece' at some stage. Similar to the first diagram, White is rolling his kingside pawns, not caring about the stranded knight on a3. Here, however, Black has just pushed ...g5 (which is usually an excellent reaction for Black in similar situations - try to remember it!), and we will get tactical play, White will be 'missing a piece' and Black has a great position in this second diagram. The first game I have selected features a somewhat different position, but shows well the trouble White can face when he has stranded knight on a3. The passive knight on a3 Game 14 AR Salem Saleh 2690 Nodirbek Abdusattorov 2661 Sharjah 2022

1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 e6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 Nc6

Our Sicilian Hedgehog exploration starts with the Paulsen Variation. In this case, White wants to avoid the Paulsen by opting for a Hedgehog set-up. In my opinion, this Taimanov Hedgehog type is less dangerous for Black than the Hedgehog coming from the Kan Variation, and therefore all other examples in this chapter will arise from the Kan. The main disadvantage of this Taimanov-type Hedgehog is that White's knight lands on a3 and needs time to be brought back into play.

5.Nb5 d6 6.c4 Nf6 7.N1c3 a6 8.Na3

I think the Kan Hedgehog, where White's knight is on the d4-square, is much more dangerous for Black. That said, 12th World Champion Anatoly Karpov favoured this line as White throughout his career, so White's set-up definitely has venom. However, in quite a number of games White lost in this variation, he neglected to bring his Na3 back into play. This recent game is a great example!

8...Be7

For younger readers, it may be interesting to know that in one of the most famous games in this variation Black opted for a gambit: 8...d5?! 9.cxd5 exd5 10.exd5 Nb4

11.Be2 Bc5.

We clearly see the influence of the computer engine on chess preparation as the famous 16th game Karpov-Kasparov from the World Championship Match, Moscow 1985, continued 12.O-O (both teams of seconds who were helping the actors missed that White has a simple solution in 12.Be3! Bxe3 13.Qa4+ Nd7 14.Qxb4 Bc5

15.Qe4+, demonstrated by Karpov a couple of months later in Karpov-Van der Wiel,

Brussels 1986. Interestingly, Van der Wiel managed to hold a draw, but the variation was closed after this) 12...O-O 13.Bf3 Bf5 14.Bg5 Re8 15.Qd2 b5. After a tense fight Kasparov won brilliantly, and I strongly recommend the reader to analyse that game.

9.Be2 O-O 10.O-O b6 11.Be3 Bb7

In some opening manuals you will find 11...Ne5 given as the most precise for Black so as after 12.Qb3 to be able to play 12...Ned7. This set-up with Nf6 & Nd7 is very flexible and was played by quite a number of top players. For many years I also thought that 11...Ne5 was the most precise; however, recent developments (this Abdusattorov game included) shed new light on this.

12.Qb3

12...Nd7

A) In his first outing vs Karpov in this line, Kasparov went for a novelty that worked out badly, but actually the idea is much better than its reputation: 12...Na5!?. Garry's idea found no followers due to the game outcome, but it looks playable for Black: 13.Qxb6 Nxe4 14.Nxe4 Bxe4 15.Qxd8 Bxd8 16.Rad1. And here Black can improve on Kasparov's play with 16...Bf6! (in the game Black probably miscalculated something; after 16...d5? 17.f3 Bf5 18.cxd5 exd5 19.Rxd5 Be6 20.Rd6 Bxa2 21.Rxa6 White was a sound pawn up and soon won in Karpov- Kasparov, Moscow 1984) 17.b3 (17.Bd4 Be7 is about equal) 17...Nc6 18.f3 (White can sacrifice an exchange with 18.Rxd6 Be7 19.c5 Bxd6 20.cxd6 when he has compensation but not more) and now comes the important move 18...Bb2! 19.Nb1 Bxb1 20.Rxb1 (only Black can be better in case of 20.Rxd6 Bxa2 21.Rxc6 Rfb8)

20...Ba3 21.f4 a5. White's queenside majority cannot advance, Black has a stable

position and can play ...Bc5 at any time he chooses, trading the bishops. The position is about equal; B) If Black is willing to adopt the above-mentioned set-up with Nd7/Nf6, he can still reach it by playing 12...Ne5 (this possibility was completely omitted by old theory!) as after 13.Bxb6 (13.f3 Ned7 and we have the standard set-up) 13...Qd7 Black has great compensation for the sacrificed pawn - White's pieces are poorly coordinated here; C) Black also has interesting option in a move that has not been played yet at the time of writing, so strange enough it would be a novelty: 12...Rb8 analysis diagram followed by ...Ba8, with complicated play. The pawn grab is risky and probably not advisable: 13.Bxb6 (13.Qxb6 is not even a pawn grab; after 13...Qxb6 14.Bxb6 Ba8 White has to give his pawn back and Black has excellent play, e.g. 15.c5 dxc5

16.Nc4 Nd4) 13...Qc8 14.Be3 Ba8 15.Qc2. White has lost time on the pawn win.

Black is harmoniously developed, White's Na3 is badly placed. Black opens up the centre and has sufficient compensation: 15...Nb4 16.Qb1 Qb7 (16...d5 also comes into consideration) 17.f3 (17.Bf3? is wrong due to 17...Nc6! 18.b3 Ne5 and Black has a clear advantage) 17...d5 and for the price of only one pawn Black has excellent play. Now, it is logical for White is to develop one of his rooks. Question: which rook to which file?

13.Rfd1

A number of strong players have opted for this move. I would personally prefer

13.Rad1 followed by Nab1, aiming to quickly solve the Na3 problem.

White can also postpone the decision about his rooks and improve his queen first:

13.Qc2 Nc5 14.Qd2 and after a few more moves, 14...Bf6 15.f3 Be5 16.Rf2,

the situation is in a way similar to our game. Black did not choose the right plan here with 16...Qh4. Black's planned queen activity will only give White the time to coordinate his forces (the correct decision was similar to Abdusattorov's in our game: 16...f5! and Black is ready to open up the position while White still needs to redeploy his Na3. After 17.exf5, interestingly Black gets good play with either recapture: 17...exf5 / Rxf5 18.Nd5 Ne7) 17.g3 Qf6

18.Rd1 Qg6

19.Nab1!. White has coordinated his forces and is now ready for action. 19...Rad8

20.f4! Bxc3 21.Nxc3. White has well-coordinated pieces, the bishop pair, and more

space, while Black's queen is 'overdeveloped'. 21...Ne7 22.f5! exf5. White has a winning advantage, but, as usual, precision is needed: 23.exf5! (the game Lupulescu-Nisipeanu, Khanty-Mansiysk 2009, went 23.Bxc5 bxc5 24.exf5 Qf6 and was later drawn) 23...Nxf5 24.Bxc5. Now Black is forced into a piece sacrifice that doesn't work: 24...Nxg3 (24...bxc5?? loses a piece for nothing after the simple 25.Bd3 Bc8 26.Qf4) 25.hxg3 Qxg3+

26.Kf1 Qh3+ 27.Ke1 bxc5.

analysis diagram White probably evaluated this position wrongly and therefore went for 23.Bxc5. Yes, at the moment Black does have three pawns for the piece, but White's pieces are better coordinated and his king is actually quite safe. After 28.Qf4 White has a winning advantage as Black's king will soon become a target.

13...Nc5 14.Qc2 Bf6

15.f3?

White is making seemingly standard Hedgehog moves, but probably he was not aware of Black's plan. I do not know whether Nodirbek knew Mamedyarov's game from 16 years earlier, but Shakhriyar went for exactly the same plan! 15.Rac1 Be5

16.Nab1.

Black is ready to open up the position: 16...f5! 17.f4! (White defends in the best way under the circumstances; after 17.exf5 his king would quickly become a target and Black has a pleasant choice between 17...Rxf5 and the more inventive 17...Ne7)

17...Bxc3 18.Nxc3 fxe4 19.a3 (White will get his pawn back, but Black has excellent

play) 19...e5 20.Nd5

20...Nd4 (this allows a relative simplification into equality. A good alternative was

20...a5!? when Black has the advantage after 21.fxe5 Nxe5 22.Bxc5 bxc5 23.Qxe4

a4!) 21.Bxd4 exd4 22.Rxd4 Ne6 23.Rxe4 Bxd5 24.cxd5 Nxf4 (Black does not have enough pieces for a real attack on White's king) 25.Bf3 (better was 25.Bg4 Qg5

26.Be6+ with approximate equality) 25...Qg5 26.Ree1 Rf6 27.Kh1 Raf8 28.Be4

Rh6. Black's situation has improved in the last couple of moves, but White is far from getting mated. White now made a terrible blunder, bringing the game to an abrupt end: 29.Rf1?? (he had to go for 29.Qc3) 29...Rxh2+! 0-1, Naiditsch-Mamedyarov, Fügen 2006. White first loses his queen and then more: 30.Kxh2 Qh5+ 31.Kg1 Ne2+

32.Qxe2 Qxe2 33.Bxh7+ Kxh7 34.Rxf8 Qe3+.

15...Be5 16.Bf1

[diagram]
White's knight is still stranded on a3 and Mamedyarov's plan now works much better! Black is clearly better here. The position opens up, and White is in essence a piece down (the Na3). It is difficult when a player has to choose between different bad possibilities. Salem takes a reasonable practical decision:

17.f4

An attempt at some flashy defence like 17.exf5 Rxf5 18.Nd5 fails as the knight is not doing much on d5 and Black has several good ways to achieve a winning advantage:

18...Qh4 (the simple 18...Ne7 should work well too) 19.f4 Raf8 20.fxe5 exd5

21.cxd5 Nxe5 and Black has a winning attack.

17...Bxc3 18.Qxc3 Nxe4 19.Qb3

White has the bishop pair, will get his pawn back, and if he doesn't get mated he will probably survive. White's biggest problem? Playing a complicated position essentially a piece down (the Na3)!

19...Rb8

The immediate attack 19...g5 was probably even stronger.

20.Bxb6

Stockfish suggests trying to bring the knight into play by 20.Nb1 as a better chance to survive. Well, Black has two good options here: 20...Nc5, keeping his extra pawn, or going for an attack with 20...g5.

20...Qh4 21.Qe3

21.g3 is similar to the game situation after 21...Qe7 22.Qe3 and Black opens the

white king's position with either 22...g5 or 22...e5 - a pleasant choice.

[diagram]
As said, 21...g5! was also good.

22.g3 Qf6 23.Bg2 exf4 24.gxf4

24.Qxf4? loses tons of material after 24...Qxb2 25.Qe3 Nc3.

24...Qg6

Now White attemps to finally bring his knight back into play:

25.Nc2

25...Ne5!

Direct and strong. Stockfish prefers 25...Ba8 26.Ne1 Rfe8 and either White loses his bishop (on b6) or he gets mated: 27.Bd4 Nxd4 28.Qxd4 (28.Rxd4 Nc3) 28...Nc3

29.Qxc3 Rxe1+ 30.Rxe1 Qxg2#.

26.Qe2

26.fxe5 loses to 26...f4 followed by ...f3.

26...Ng4 27.Rd3 Nef6

White simply has too many hanging pieces.

28.Bd4 Rfe8 29.Qf1 Nh5 30.Rd2

Black chooses a nice finish:

30...Re4!

30...Qh6 also wins.

31.Re1 Rxf4 32.Qd3 Nf2!

And White resigned. The 'Kan Hedgehog' Diagrammed is the Hedgehog position arising from the Kan Sicilian (this type of Hedgehog may also arise from the English Opening). White's knight is now placed on d4 and does not need to be improved. Black has just opted for one of the typical counterplay plans by pushing ...h5. I have selected three games here and hope they will give the reader a 'good grip' on the right timing of the h-pawn push for Black and how to deal with it as White. This diagram shows the dilemma White often faces. Black has just pushed ...h3 and White must decide how to react. In this position he should take gxh3!. The silicon brain also tends to take the pawn in such situations. Black's h-pawn push Game 15 Veselin Topalov 2737 Rustam Kasimdzhanov 2652 Tripoli FIDE-Wch KO 2004 We have here a top-level example of Black's h-pawn push and a poor reaction to it on White's part.

1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 e6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 a6 5.c4 Nf6 6.Nc3 Qc7 7.a3 b6 8.Be3 Bb7 9.f3

d6 10.Be2 Be7 11.O-O O-O 12.Qd2 Nbd7 13.Rac1 Rac8 14.Rfd1 Qb8 15.Bf1 Rfe8

16.Kh1 Bd8

Both sides have been playing typical Hedgehog moves. Black has not shown his hand yet. He can still choose between all three standard plans: the h-pawn push, the plan with ...Bc7, ...Kh8, ...Rg8, ...g5, or staying flexible and aiming for a timely ...d5 pawn break. Topalov plays another regular Hedgehog move:

17.Bg1

Now Kasim shows his hand:

[diagram]
How should White react? As we will also see in the comments to the next game, Dominguez-Andreikin, most white players prefer not to touch the h-pawn. Topalov takes the same 'human' approach as Dominguez did: 'do not touch the h-pawn, do not risk creating a weakness'.

18.Qf2

White's best reaction was 18.h3 when after the logical 18...h4 19.Bh2 Nh5 analysis diagram

20.Nde2! covers the g3-square and makes sure White keeps the dark- squared

bishop: 20...Ne5 21.b3 Be7. As mentioned in a similar situation in the game Dominguez-Andreikin, e3 is a good square for the white queen here: 22.Qe3! and White is ready to push f4. The silicon brain prefers White. In human play I would say the game is unclear.

18...Ne5

Black's pawn could have continued on its journey: 18...h4. Most probably, Rustam did not play this because he was not sure about the position resulting after the following pawn sacrifice: 19.h3 (Black is at least okay after the pawn structure change with 19.Qxh4 Nxe4) 19...Nh5. Now White has to part with his bishop:

20.Bh2 (20.Nce2? is not good due to 20...Ne5 21.b3 b5!)

analysis diagram

20...Ng3+! 21.Bxg3 hxg3 22.Qxg3 Nf6. The bishop pair is important here as Black

will open up the position with the ...d5 break at some stage; Black has sufficient compensation.

19.b3 Ng6 20.b4?

The right approach was to touch the h-pawn: 20.h3! h4 21.Bh2 Nh5 22.Nde2.

20...h4 21.Nb3

Black now accomplishes his plan:

[diagram]
Should White take the black pawn or should he ignore it? The decision is difficult as White is clearly worse in both cases. Veselin decides to ignore the pawn.

22.g3

In an ideal world (it will not happen in this position) White hopes to preserve his pawn structure while at some stage collecting the pawn with Bxh3. Unfortunately for White, he does not get the opportunity to do this. In answer to 22.gxh3 Black has different good options. The most straightforward central pawn break is a good one: 22...d5 (22...Ne5 and later breaking with ...d5 is also good) 23.exd5 exd5. analysis diagram A) White gets devastated if he plays 24.cxd5 Rxc3 (the simple 24...Qa8 followed by ...Nxd5 is also not bad) 25.Rxc3 Nxd5 (White's pieces have poor coordination; Black has a winning advantage) 26.Rcd3 Bh4 27.Qd4 Ngf4 etc.; B) 24.c5 Nd7 (also better for Black are the positions resulting from the thematic pawn sac 24...d4 25.Rxd4 Bc7) 25.Nxd5 Nde5 26.Bg2 Qa8 - White cannot defend on the a8-h1 diagonal and this will prove decisive here.

22...Ne5 23.Rd4

Here Kasimdzhanov made the only mistake in this game, agreeing to a draw by move repetition:

23...Nc6?

Black has a large, close to winning advantage. Best would have been to open up the position further with 23...b5! and White does not have a good way to keep his stuff together. Black's bishop coming to b6 is very unpleasant for White: 24.c5 dxc5

25.Nxc5 Bb6.

analysis diagram White would love to solve the problem of the pin on the a7-g1 diagonal and also finally collect the h3-pawn... but he cannot get it done: 26.Rdd1 (26.Bxh3? loses to

26...Nfd7 27.Rdd1 Nxc5 28.bxc5 Bxc5 29.Qe2 Bxa3) 26...Qa8!. The pressure along

the a8-h1 diagonal has been increased while Black's queen no longer hangs once Black plays ...Nd7 and White takes. White's best option here is to finally grab the annoying pawn: 27.Bxh3 Nfd7. ...Nxc5 is coming, and White is in a bad shape here, while 28.Qd4 only delays the inevitable. Black has a large advantage after 28...f6 or

28...Rcd8 29.Qe3 Nxc5 30.bxc5 Ba5 31.Bg2 Nc4.

23...Qa8, though less forcing, leads to Black's advantage too.

24.Rdd1 Ne5 25.Rd4 Nc6?

1⁄2-1⁄2 White pushes a4, Black responds ...a5 Game 16 Leinier Dominguez Perez 2726 Dmitry Andreikin 2687 Havana 2011

1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 e6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 a6 5.c4 Nf6 6.Nc3 Bb4 7.Bd2 Qc7 8.a3 Be7

9.Be3 d6 10.Be2 O-O 11.O-O b6 12.Qd2 Bb7 13.f3 Nbd7 14.Rfc1!?

We do not often see the rooks positioned on a1 and c1 in such positions. White has a specific plan in mind (similar to Agrest-Nisipeanu below).

14...Rac8 15.a4!?

The standard queenside pawn push 15.b4 is certainly an option here. Like in Agrest-Nisipeanu, White wants to push a5 and Black stops this in an unusual way!

[diagram]
I have rarely seen such a pawn structure - actually I cannot recall any other top game with it! Black stops White's pawn advance at the expense of giving White the b5- square. How important is it? Is White better here? It doesn't look that way. White has the b5-square for his knight, but Black's knight has obtained a very stable post on c5. Black seems to have no problems defending his d6-pawn, so the position is probably balanced. What alternative plans did Black have? Advancing the h-pawn is a standard plan, so let's see how it works here: 15...h5 16.b4. A) If 16.a5 bxa5 17.Nb3, White does accomplish his plan of bringing his knight to a5, however after 17...h4 18.Nxa5 Ba8 analysis diagram Black has adequate counterplay, White does not have a free hand to push his queenside pawns. One way for White to deal with Black's h-pawn advance is to bring his knight to f2:

16.Nd1. Now, if Black wants to, he can also push 16...a5 and have a reasonably good

version of the game; B) 16.b4 h4 (trying to use the fact that White's b4-pawn is not protected and going for a central break with 16...d5 may backfire as White has the strong piece sacrifice

17.Nxd5! exd5 18.cxd5 Qb8 19.Nf5; 16...Ne5 does not worry White as he has

17.Nd1) 17.a5 bxa5 18.Rxa5.

analysis diagram After 18...Ne5! (the immediate 18...h3 allows the nice rook swing 19.Rg5! and it is White who will attack on the kingside!) the position is unclear. Initially, the engine slightly prefers White, however there are many dynamic/tactical ideas: 19.Nd1 (if

19.h3 - White wants to play 20. f4 - Black has his trumps: 19...Nh5! (the pawn grab

19...Nxc4?? blunders the queen: 20.Bxc4 Qxc4 21.Nce2) 20.f4 Ng3! 21.fxe5 dxe5

the whole board is hanging; Stockfish gives zeros) 19...h3 20.g3 (20.gxh3 is possible but quite risky here). analysis diagram In an ideal world, White wants to keep his kingside pawn structure intact and collect Black's pawn with Nd1-f2-h3. 20...Qd7 (Black also has piece sacrifice ideas:

20...Bxe4!? 21.fxe4 Nxe4 22.Qe1 Qb7) 21.Nf2 and now is the time for the central

pawn break 21...d5 with an unclear game. Was 15...h5 an option? Yes, it certainly was. Another possibility was 15...Qb8 and in case of 16.a5 bxa5 17.Rxa5 (White cannot bring his knight to a5 as 17.Nb3? blunders a pawn to 17...Bxe4) 17...Ne5 it is not easy for White to advance further on the kingside; the position is balanced.

16.Ndb5 Qb8

17.Bf4

White wants to take advantage of his knight on b5 and put pressure on the d6-pawn. Anther way to do this was 17.Re1 Rcd8 18.Rad1 Nc5 19.Bf4. analysis diagram The pawn win appears not to bring White any advantage here: 19...Nh5! 20.Bxd6 Bxd6 21.Nxd6 e5 and the Nc5 is well placed while the Be2 locked up by its own pawns; Black is definitely not worse, e.g. 22.Qg5 (or 22.Ncb5 Bc6) 22...Rxd6

23.Qxh5 Rxd1 24.Rxd1 Bc6.

Dominguez most probably rejected 17.Rd1 because matters don't look clear after

17...Nc5.

17...Ne5 18.b3 Rfd8 19.Kh1

Andreikin now decides in favour of one of Black's standard Hedgehog plans: pushing the h-pawn:

19...h5

The alternative was to bring Nf6 to the nice c5 outpost with 19...Nfd7 20.Rd1 Nc5

21.Rab1 when the position is probably about equal.

How should White react to Black's pawn push? What I noticed is that most white players prefer not to touch their h-pawn, and here this is also the case.

20.Bf1

In this and most similar positions, Stockfish has much less trouble 'creating weaknesses' and happily plays 20.h3!. Now, after the most logical follow-up 20...h4

21.Bh2, Black seems to be doing well optically - one knight goes to h5, another to

g6, dark-square control... However, in practice it does not work that well here, for example 21...Ng6 (21...Nh5?? blunders a piece after the simple 22.f4) 22.Qe3! (the white queen is well placed on e3; it prepares the f4-push while also subsequently covering the g3-square) 22...Bc6 23.Rd1. White has a relatively simple plan here: double the rooks to keep Black busy defending the d6-pawn, and then at a convenient moment push f4. Black does not have an easy life here, as counterplay attempts like 23...Nh5 lose a pawn for no compensation after 24.f4 Ng3+ 25.Bxg3 hxg3 26.Bh5 Nf8 27.Qxg3.

20...h4

Now Black is fine. The position is about equal but probably easier to play with Black.

21.Qf2

21.h3 now does not bring the same result as after 21...Nh5 22.Bh2 Ng6

analysis diagram

23.Qf2 (in reply to 23.Ne2, Black has a nice idea in 23...Rc5! and White can easily

get in trouble, e.g. 24.Qe3? Bg5! 25.f4 Bh6 with the threat 26...e5; White's pawns are shaky and the evaluation is minus two!) 23...Ng3+! 24.Bxg3 hxg3 25.Qxg3 Bf6 Black has excellent compensation for his sacrificed pawn.

21...Rc5

Black is getting ready for the typical Hedgehog break ...d5. Could Black immediately go for 21...d5 ? Yes, he could. It does require some good calculation though: 22.cxd5 Nd3! 23.Bxd3 Qxf4 24.Qxb6. analysis diagram At moments like these, a human player often stops calculating and (instead of

21...d5!?) looks for some other moves (like 21...Rc5 in the game - so that b6 will not

be hanging). Black is actually doing pretty well here: 24...Bxd5! 25.exd5 (25.Ne2?? blunders into the simple 25...Rxc1+ 26.Rxc1 Qd2) 25...Nxd5. Black gets his sacrificed piece back, and White is the one who needs to be careful here: 26.Qg1! Nxc3 27.Nxc3 Rxd3 and White bails out into a drawn rook endgame with 28.Nd5! Rxc1 29.Nxe7+ Kf8 30.Qxc1 Qxc1+ 31.Rxc1 Kxe7 32.h3. A draw will be the outcome of this tactical tussle: 32...Kd6 33.Rc8 Rxb3 34.Ra8 etc.

22.Be3 d5!

Black judges well that the central break works and goes for it. For a better understanding of this position it is good to notice that in the event of

22...Ng6!? 23.Bxc5 dxc5, Black has full compensation for the sacrificed exchange.

analysis diagram For example, 24.Rd1 Rf8! followed by ...Nh5 and ...f5.

23.exd5 exd5 24.cxd5

Andreikin ignores the threat to his rook and decides to weaken White's king position.

24...h3! 25.Rd1

Black is fine in the event of 25.Bxc5 Bxc5 26.Qg3 as White has to give his extra exchange back: 26...hxg2+ 27.Bxg2 Nd3 28.Rc2 Nf2+ 29.Rxf2 Qxg3 30.hxg3 Bxf2

31.Kh2 Bc5. Black has suffient compensation for the pawn and is not worse here.

(Of course not 31...Nxd5?? which blunders into a pin and material loss) after

32.Rd1.)

25...Nxd5 26.Bxc5 Bxc5 27.Qg3 Nxc3

The position is sharp, but still approximately equal.

28.Rxd8+?

Most probably a time-pressure blunder.

28.Nxc3 led to a forced sequence of moves with a drawish outcome: 28...hxg2+

(28...Bd4 transposes after 29.f4! hxg2+ 30.Bxg2 Bxg2+ 31.Qxg2 Bxc3= etc.)

29.Bxg2 Bd4 30.f4!.

analysis diagram And we get a peaceful outcome after 30...Bxg2+ 31.Qxg2 Bxc3 32.Rxd8+ Qxd8

33.Rc1 and now a few more pieces leave the board: 33...Bb2 (or 33...Ng6 34.Rxc3

Qd1+ 35.Qg1 Qd5+=) 34.Qxb2 Nd3 35.Qd2 Qa8+ 36.Kg1 Nxc1 37.Qxc1 with a dead drawn queen ending.

28...Qxd8!

Black's threats are obvious, White either suffers decisive material loss or gets mated.

29.Qxe5

Or 29.Nxc3 Qd4.

29...Nd1 30.Ra2 Ne3 31.Nc3 Nxf1 32.Re2 Nd2 33.Qg3 hxg2+ 34.Rxg2 g6 0-1

White pushes the a-pawn, Black counters with his h-pawn Game 17 Evgenij Agrest 2554 Liviu-Dieter Nisipeanu 2584 Batumi Ech-tt 1999

1.c4 e6 2.Nc3 b6 3.e4 Bb7 4.Nf3 c5 5.d4 cxd4 6.Nxd4 d6 7.Be2 Nf6 8.f3 a6 9.Be3

Nbd7 This position can also arise from the Kan Sicilian. If Black is worried about White's a-pawn push, he can delay developing the Nb8 with 9...Be7 10.O-O O-O when 11.a4 doesn't achieve its aim due to 11...Nc6.

10.O-O Be7

And now White goes for a plan similar to Dominguez-Andreikin.

11.a4 O-O 12.a5 bxa5 13.Nb3 Rb8 14.Nxa5 Ba8 15.Qd2

White has achieved his aim: his knight is well placed on a5, his queenside pawns are ready to move. White's plan is simple: push the b-pawn. Black cannot really stop this, so he urgently needs to find something. What is Black's best counterplan here? Answer: pushing the h-pawn. Nisipeanu ultimately understands this, but he loses precious time in the process!

15...Re8?!

On this move or the next, Black had to start with the immediate 15...h5! with sufficient counterplay.

16.Kh1 Qc7?! 17.Rfc1

With his last two moves, Black has not really improved his position, while White is ready to push his b-pawn.

17...Ne5 18.Bd4

Black now decides on the right counterplay; however, precious time has been lost. Black is in trouble here.

18...h5! 19.b4! h4

19...Rxb4?? was bad due to the simple 20.Nb5 axb5 21.Qxb4 and White is an

exchange up with a better position.

20.b5!

Black cannot stop White on the queenside, so for better or worse, he needs to keep pushing his pawn:

20...h3

The critical moment. How should White react?

21.g3?

Agrest reacts in a way similar to Topalov and Dominguez: preserve the structure, collect the pawn on h3 later. Correct was 21.gxh3! when Black has many tactical ideas, but they don't work. White has a large advantage. The pawn will stay on h3 until the end of the game and due to White's king weakness Nisipeanu eventually saves the game.

21...axb5 22.cxb5

Putting the queen on c7 was not a good idea in the first place.

22...Qd8!

Now White creates a strong passer on c6, probably thinking he had a winning advantage.

23.Bxe5 dxe5 24.Qxd8 Rexd8 25.Nc6 Bxc6 26.bxc6

Black saves the game due to White's weak king; the pawn on h3 is doing an excellent job.

26...Rd2 27.Ba6

Or 27.Bf1 Rbb2 28.Ne2 Bd8! 29.c7 Bxc7 30.Rxc7 Rxe2 31.Bxe2 Rxe2 with a draw like in the game.

27...Rbb2

The silicon brain will explain that 27...Ne8 was good as well, but the text is more human.

28.Ne2 Bd6 29.c7 Bxc7 30.Rxc7 Rxe2 31.Bxe2 Rxe2

White's king is 'inside the box' and the extra exchange doesn't matter here.

32.Rf1 g5 33.g4 Kg7 34.Kg1 Rg2+ 35.Kh1 Re2 36.Rc3 Nd7 37.Rfc1 Rf2 38.Kg1

Rg2+ 39.Kh1 Rf2 1⁄2-1⁄2 Fresh ideas for White The diagrammed position comes from the Kan Sicilian. Here we see a relatively new concept that will be more deeply explored! White has just pushed g4 and is starting a Scheveningen-type pawn storm. Do NOT confuse this with the first two introductory diagrams in this chapter as here the situation is VERY different. White's knight is well-placed on d4, so he does not run the risk of 'missing a piece'. White's attack can develop fast here! Game 18 Yasser Seirawan Nick de Firmian Estes Park 1986

1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 e6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 a6 5.c4 Nf6 6.Nc3 Qc7

7.Be2!?

The text move is considerably less often played than 7.a3, but to me it is far from clear which move is the most precise. Black has two logical options: a) continue Hedgehog development with 7...b6 or b) try to exploit the fact that White hasn't played 7.a3 and play 7...Bb4. Let's have a look at both.

7...b6

A) 7...Bc5, played by Bronstein, does not look inspiring: 8.Be3 d6 9.O-O Bd7 10.a3 O-O 11.b4 Ba7 12.Rc1 White has a typical Hedgehog position while Black looks passive. White is going to trade the dark- squared bishops (a good trade for White here!): 12...Rc8 13.Qd2 Be8

14.Rfd1 Nbd7 15.Nb3 Bxe3 16.Qxe3 Ne5 17.c5 with an easy, risk-free advantage.

(17.h3 was played in Honfi-Bronstein, Miskolc 1963. White later spoiled his position and even lost.) B) 7...Bb4

8.O-O (8.Qd3 can of course be played - probably transposing to 9.Qd3 below - but

White should not really object to Black grabbing a pawn here) and now: B1) 8...Bxc3 9.bxc3 Nxe4 is asking for trouble after 10.Bf3 Nc5 11.Nb3

11...d6 (11...O-O? leads more or less to a lost position after 12.Nxc5! - 12.Qd4 d6

13.Rd1 was played in Shirov-Fedorov, Riga 2014, where Black eventually survived

- 12...Qxc5 13.Qa4 and Black simply cannot develop). Now White can reach a better ending with a relatively forced sequence: 12.Bf4 e5 13.Nxc5 Qxc5 14.Be3 Qc7

15.Qd5 O-O 16.Rfd1 Nc6 17.Qxd6 Qxd6 18.Rxd6 with play for two results: maybe

Black makes a draw, maybe not; B2) 8...O-O 9.Qd3 d6 10.Bd2. Similar to Bronstein's 7...Bc5, we have a Hedgehog position with the black bishop 'out'. To me, the bishop looks more natural on e7 in these positions. 10...Nbd7 (to

10...Nc6, probably White's best reaction is 11.Nxc6! bxc6 and now he can take

space 12.a3 Bc5 13.b4 Ba7 14.Bg5 with an easy advantage) 11.Nb3 Ne5 12.Qd4 Nc6 13.Qe3 Bd7 14.Rac1 Rac8. White now took the bishop pair with 15.a3 and had an advantage in Naiditsch-Ivanchuk, Danzhou 2017. White has two dangerous 'Sicilian pawn storm plans' here (both a little unusual for the Kan Hedgehog). In both cases Black holds a dynamic balance... if... a computer is playing.

8.Be3

The other option is 8.O-O Bb7 9.Qd3

9...d6 (9...Nc6 leads to a safe advantage for White after 10.Nxc6! Bxc6 11.Be3 Bc5

12.Bxc5 bxc5 13.f4 with d-file pressure and more space, Shomoev-Khismatullin,

Khanty-Mansiysk 2015). A) Now White can start a standard Sicilian pawn storm with 10.f4 Nbd7 11.b4 Be7

12.Be3 O-O 13.Rac1

13...Rac8 (13...Rad8? runs into a textbook tactic: 14.Nd5! exd5 15.cxd5 and White

got his piece back - 15...Qb8 is refuted by 16.Nc6 - and had a clear advantage in Khalifman-Akopian, Minsk 2014). Now we have an interesting situation: White starts a 'Scheveningen Sicilian pawn storm'! 14.g4!. White has five pawns on the fourth rank and yet he isn't overstretched! A1) 14...Qd8 15.g5. Now White has a winning advantage. This is a Hedgehog where the Scheveningen pawn storm works perfectly for White: 15...Ne8 16.Qd2

16...Nc7 (breaks of the 16...d5 type sometimes save Black in similar situations... but

not here! 17.cxd5 Bxb4 18.dxe6 Nc5. Now White first wins an exchange and later probably the game with the tactic 19.Nc6! Qxd2 20.Bxd2 Rxc6 21.e7) 17.a3 Re8

18.Nb3 (Stronger was just continuing the Scheveningen pawn storm with 18.h4!.

White has advanced so many of his pawns and yet Black does not have a good pawn break!) 18...f6 19.h4! Rf8. White understands he needs his Nb3 as an attacking piece: 20.Nd4! fxg5 21.hxg5 and White had a winning attack in Brkic-Gajewski, Jerusalem 2015 (1-0, 43); A2) Black is perhaps not worse if... a computer is playing, after 14...h6! 15.h4 analysis diagram

15...h5! 16.g5 Ng4 17.Bxg4 hxg4 18.Nce2. It looks like 19. Ng3 next will be

slaughter but Black has defensive resources: 18...g6! 19.Ng3 e5!. analysis diagram Now White has several beautiful ideas, all leading to a 'zeros' evaluation: 20.Ndf5! (or 20.h5 exd4 21.Bxd4 Ne5!) 20...gxf5 21.Nxf5. To a human player this looks terribly dangerous for Black but apparently the position is dynamically balanced:

21...Rce8! 22.Nh6+ Kh7 23.f5 and it all ends peacefully with a move repetition:

23...Qc6 24.Qd5 Qc7 25.Qd3 Qc6.

B) An interesting novel idea is 10.Qg3!? Nbd7 (the pawn grab 10...Nxe4?! 11.Nxe4 Bxe4 is at least risky: 12.Re1 Nc6 13.Bf3! Bxf3 14.Qxf3 Rc8. analysis diagram Black's pawn defences need to be destroyed: 15.Nxe6! fxe6 16.Rxe6+ Be7 17.Bg5 and Black is in bad shape; 17...Nd4? loses to 18.Qh5+ g6 19.Rxg6) 11.f3. analysis diagram It looks logical to fianchetto the bishop here: 11...g6 12.Be3 Bg7 13.Rac1 O-O. At first glance, this looks like a normal Hedgehog, but my Stockfish is very enthusiastic for White, evaluating plus one!

8...Bb7 9.f3 d6

It is perhaps useful to mention that 9...Bd6? is a tempo loss as after 10.Qd2 White threatens 11. Ndb5 and Black has nothing better than 10...Be7 (10...Bxh2 loses to

11.O-O-O with many threats). White is simply a tempo up compared to regular lines

and here went for the most aggressive continuation 11.O-O-O Nc6 12.Kb1 Ne5

13.Rc1 and White went on to win in Ivanchuk-Kamsky, lichess.org blitz 2020.

10.O-O Be7 11.Rc1 Nbd7

We have our standard Kan Sicilian Hedgehog with the difference that White has not played a3. If White wants a queenside a3, b4 build up he can still play 12.a3, transposing. However, White can also opt for a much more aggressive set-up!

12.Qe1!? O-O

And now White goes for a Sicilian pawn storm!

13.g4!

White is combining Hedgehog central control with a Sicilian pawn roll. Please note that White can also apply similar plans in lines with 7.a3. It just looks to me that if White is willing to go for such a set-up, this is the best move-order and the most efficient way to do it. The resulting positions are very sharp and easy to get wrong. It started as a standard Hedgehog but now the only thing making this a Hedgehog is White's pawn on c4, otherwise we have an open Sicilian where White applies a bayonet pawn roll on the kingside! Interestingly, there are almost no games here! We have one top-level game from almost forty years ago, then one game between top engines, and not much else - definitely an area to explore further! The first tough decision for Black is whether or not to play ...h6 - never an easy decision in such positions. In our human top-level game and also in the engines' top- level game, Black opted for 13...h6.

13...h6

Allowing White to roll his pawns undisturbed is not a good idea; after 13...Ne8 14.g5 g6 15.h4 Ng7 16.f4 Rfe8 17.f5 exf5 18.Nd5 Qd8 19.exf5 White was clearly better and easily won in Wagner-Sachdev, Biel 2018.

14.h4 Nh7

White gets ready to bring his rook to the h-file.

15.Kg2

White could also roll his pawns differently with 15.Qg3. If Black wants to follow Komodo's type of play with 15...Qd8 (see the next comment) White can continue with 16.Rcd1 Re8 (16...Bxh4 17.Qxd6 is probably better for White) and now: A) Pawn sacrifice ideas like 17.g5 hxg5 18.hxg5 Bxg5 19.f4 are not easy to evaluate: 19...Bf6 20.Rd2 and White's rook will swing to the kingside; my Stockfish evaluates around zeros... not easy to tell; B) 17.Rd2, preparing the g5 push (to sacrifice a pawn under better circumstances) is also an option; C) 17.Bf2 Rc8 18.f4 with interesting play. I would personally prefer to be White, but is a matter of taste. Yasser Seirawan took a drastic step to stop White's pawn roll:

[diagram]
In a high-level computer game, Komodo went for 15...Qd8. Obviously, these engines are much stronger than me, while to use my weaker engine to analyse top engine games looks stupid. So I will just give some moves of that game: 16.Rh1 Re8

17.Qg3 Ndf8 18.f4 (18.Rcd1 is an alternative)

It looks as if Black will fall victim to White's bayonet pawn roll, but Black has resources: 18...Bf6! 19.g5 hxg5 20.fxg5 (Black can counter 20.hxg5 with 20...Bxd4

21.Bxd4 e5 22.fxe5 Qxg5 with sharp play, my 'weak Stockfish' giving me zeros)

20...Be5 21.Qg4 f5! 22.Qh3 Ng6 with a sharp game ending in a draw, Stoofvlees-

Komodo, TCEC 2020.

16.hxg5 hxg5

Black did stop White's pawn and has also secured himself an outpost on e5; however, it's the h-file that matters! White has an advantage.

17.Rh1 Rfe8 18.Qg3 Ndf8 19.Rh6 Bf6 20.Rch1

Black is not exactly getting mated, but the pressure on the h-file is unpleasant for him here.

20...Be5 21.Qf2 Rab8

Now White improves his knight:

22.Nc2! Bc8 23.Nb4 f6 24.Nd3

Black has to part with his bishop (though doubling White's pawns).

24...Bxc3 25.bxc3 Re7

White improves his knight again:

26.Nb4! Rg7 27.Bd3 a5 28.Nc2

White's knight on d4 will annoying, while playing 28...e5 allows White to bring his knight to e3, targeting the d5- and f5-squares. White definitely has an advantage here, and Black faces unpleasant dilemmas. Yasser's problems were solved by probably the only mistake Nick made in this game - a draw offer! It was gladly accepted. Typical piece sacrifices for White The diagrammed position shows a typical piece sacrifice idea for White.Black is a piece up, there no deadly threats, and yet Black is in deep trouble! Though we have relatively little games featuring this sacrifice concept, it is dangerous for Black, and computer engines confirm this. Game 19 Pascal Charbonneau 2510 Viswanathan Anand 2803 Turin ol 2006

30.a4

This looks sharp, but 30.Nd5! leads to a winning advantage as after 30...exd5

31.cxd5 Black's bishops are killed (meaning 'no attack') and, apart from dominating,

White will also start collecting some material, e.g. 31...Ne8 (31...Bd8 loses a piece after 32.Rc8 Bb7 33.Rb8; 31...Qd8 32.Bxg5 (32.Ng3 with Nf5 to follow is also strong) 32...Nxe4 33.fxe4 Rxg5 34.Rxc7; 31...Bb8 32.Bxa6+-) 32.Bxa6 with Ng3- f5 to follow and Black's position will collapse, e.g. 32...Rh4 33.Bb5+- Bd8 34.Rc8. If 30.g4 Rh3 31.Kg2 h5! 32.Kxh3 hxg4+ 33.Kg2 Qh7 is unclear.

30...Bb7

30...Rh4, preparing the ...g4 pawn push, was logical, however White would again

have the killer 31.Nd5!! exd5 32.cxd5 Ne8 33.Bxa6 Ng3. Nf5 will follow, while Black cannot create real counterplay. Still, from a practical standpoint 30...Rh4 was perhaps the best move guided by the logic 'if White did not sac on d5 last move, it is not very likely that he will do it next move'. This is an interesting psychological moment! We are playing against an opponent but also playing against ourselves, and being a strong player (seeing your opponent's best options) does not always help!

31.c5

Could White still sacrifice a piece? The answer is: Yes! After 31.Nd5 exd5 32.cxd5 Bd8 33.Ng3 White has (similar to Hübner-Ligterink below) only one pawn for the piece but has domination and full compensation (as a minimum - and Stockfish agrees!). The game is now tense and probably dynamically balanced. This game has been analysed in many publications (including my own book Sacrifice and Initiative). Interestingly, Vishy was the one to err and the game became one of the biggest 2006 Olympiad upsets.

31...dxc5 32.bxc5 bxc5 33.Rb1 Bc6 34.Bxc5 g4! 35.f4

[diagram]
It's not easy to tell what Anand blundered, but this mistake proves crucial. 35...Nf3! was the way to go, with complicating lines resulting in equality.

36.fxe5! Nxe4 37.Nxe4 Bxe4

Most likely Black overestimated his threats. White has an easy way to deal with the problem:

38.Bd3! Bxg2+ 39.Qxg2 gxh2 40.Bxg6 Rxg6

Black has no attack here because he simply has no pieces left. White chooses an elegant finish:

41.Ng3 Rxg3 42.Qe4 Rg4 43.Be7! 1-0

43...Rxe4 44.Bf6 Qg7 45.Rb8 Bxb8 46.Rd8#.

Game 20 Robert Hübner 2620 Gert Ligterink 2445 Wijk aan Zee 1984 Another good example of a typical sacrifice idea for White. White does not need to sacrifice a piece here, but Robert Hübner's idea is instructive! If Black's bishops are tamed, White will have full domination and this can be achieved by means of a positional piece sacrifice:

29.Nd5!

White also had a reasonably promising pawn sacrifice at his disposal: 29.Ng3. A) If 29...Nxe4 30.Bxe4 Bxe4 White should not be greedy for material but should play for the initiative with 31.Re1! (Black has reasonable compensation for the exchange in the event of 31.Nh5 Kh7 32.Nxg7 Rxg7); B) After 29...Bxe4 White has an unpleasant pawn break: 30.c5! bxc5 31.bxc5 Bxb1

32.c6! and many black pieces are hanging. Black's position looks lost but he can

continue fighting: 32...Ne4 33.Nxe4 Bxe4 34.cxd7 g3! (the key move, creating mate threats) 35.h3 Qd8 36.Rd4! (36.Qxc7?? blunders into a mate after 36...Qh4) 36...Ba5

37.Qa3 Bb7 and White should be better but the game remains complicated, e.g. 38.f5

(or 38.Rb1 Ba8 39.f5) 38...Bb6 39.Rxd6 Qh4 40.Rcc6.

29...exd5 30.cxd5

From a practical perspective (compared to the 29.Ng3 lines) Hübner's choice was an excellent one! Black is now doomed to passivity and cannot think of those flashy lines shown under 29.Ng3. This is an instructive example because most of the players, when they sacrificing a piece and get only one pawn in return, will be looking for a forced justification of the sacrifice. White does not have a 'forced justification' here, but he does have domination! Black's bishops are killed and White's knight will travel to the f5-outpost.

30...Bd8

30...Rc8 31.Nd4 also looks good for White.

31.Bd4

31.Ng3! with Nf5 to follow was more precise.

31...Nh5 32.Bxg7+ Rxg7

33.Nd4

It was probably better to keep the f4-pawn (so as not to allow the blockade on e5) with 33.Rf1.

33...Nxf4 34.Nf5 Ne5 35.Nxd6 f6 36.Qe3 Nfg6 37.Rf1 Rh7

The best defence was 37...Qb8! when the situation is not clear because White has given Black an excellent blockading outpost on e5!

38.Rf5 Qb8 39.Ne8 Bc8 40.Nxf6 Bxf6

The only way to struggle on was 40...Bxf5! 41.Nxh7 Kxh7 42.exf5 Bg5! 43.fxg6+ Kg7 44.Qe1 Bxc1 45.Qxc1 Qd6.

41.Rxf6 b5 42.Rxg6 1-0

A dream position for White The diagrammed position, which occurred in a well-known top-level game, shows a dream situation for White! He has regrouped excellently and is ready to push his pawns on the queenside. Black has a badly placed queen and no counterplay. In a higher sense this position is close to lost for Black! The game is very instructive in the way White (Kasparov) regrouped his pieces and Black (Kramnik) got a terrible position due to just shuffling his pieces around and not coming with a clear plan. To have and have not a plan Can a world champion in a classical game get into a lost position by playing random moves, never achieving any counterplay? Yes, he can! So don't kick yourself if sometimes it happens to you. Game 21 Garry Kasparov 2838 Vladimir Kramnik 2802 Moscow 2001

1.e4 c5 2.Nf3 e6 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4 a6 5.c4 Nf6 6.Nc3 Qc7 7.a3 d6 8.Be3 b6 9.Rc1

Nbd7 We will get a typical Kan Hedgehog position.

10.Be2 Bb7 11.f3 Be7 12.O-O O-O 13.Kh1 Rac8 14.b4 Qb8 15.Qd2

White plans Rc2, Rb1, Na4, Nb2, Nd3, Qc1 and then simply start pushing his queenside pawns. Black obviously needs to plan some counterplay. In such positions, when it comes to planning, computer engines are less helpful than human knowledge/experience. The engine will give many options for Black evaluating at approximately 0.40. In my opinion, the plan Kramnik had to go for was pushing the h-pawn. Vladimir does not decide on a plan and keeps randomly shuffling his pieces around while Garry is executing his plan. As a result, once White's regrouping has been accomplished, he has a close to winning advantage!

15...Bd8

Black could consider 15...Rfe8 16.Rc2 h5.

16.Rc2 Re8

16...h5 again came into consideration. White continues with his plan.

17.Na4 Bc7

It was high time to start counterplay with 17...h5!.

18.Bg1

18...Rcd8?

This shows a lack of any clear plan as the ...d5 push is not really on the cards here. This was the last moment to play 18...h5! and if 19.Qe1, 19...Bd8 followed by ...h4.

19.Rb1

White is now clearly better and it's difficult to give Black clever advice.

19...Ba8

19...h5? is now wrong as there is no follow-up after the simple 20.Qe1.

20.Qc1

The next few random moves do not improve Kramnik's situation; however, without any counterplay his prospects are already bleak here.

20...h6

Kasparov takes the human decision and continues with his plan.

21.Nb2

My Stockfish is also enthusiastic about immediate action with 21.c5.

21...Nf8 22.Nd3

Regrouping accomplished! Now is the time for White to push his queenside pawns and crush Black!

22...Ng6 23.a4

Black's queen is terribly placed.

23...Qc8

White pieces are perfectly positioned for the final onslaught! Time to open the queenside. Which pawn would you push?

24.b5?

Surprising enough, Kasparov chooses for the least strong push.

24.a5 bxa5 25.b5 led to a winning advantage as Black cannot stabilize the queenside

situation:

24.c5 was perhaps strongest. At first glance Black seems to get counterplay after

24...bxc5 25.bxc5 d5.

analysis diagram However, the 'tension' lasts only a few moves: 26.e5! Nxe5 27.Nxe5 Bxe5 28.c6 and Black's queen is horribly placed. White has a winning advantage, e.g. 28...Bc7

29.Qf1!; 28...Qc7 29.Bxa6; or 28...Re7 29.Qf1.

24...a5

Black now stabilizes the queenside.

25.Nc6

It is possible that Kasparov, when deciding on 24.b5, thought that one of the pawn breaks 25.e5 or 25.c5 would work but then figured out that they didn't.

25...Bxc6

25...Rd7? is a mistake due to 26.Nxa5! bxa5 27.c5 and White crushes Black -

probably in the way he was hoping for.

26.bxc6

The lion's share of White's advantage has evaporated. Black stabilizes his situation and equalizes:

26...e5! 27.Bxb6 Ne7

28.c5

Keeping the bishop on was probably better: 28.Bg1! Nxc6 29.Rcb2.

28...d5 29.Bxc7 Qxc7 30.Rb7 Qxc6 31.Rb5 Ng6

32.exd5 Nxd5 33.Nf2 Ngf4 34.Bf1 Ne6 35.Rxa5 Qc7 36.Rb5 Nd4 37.Rc4 Nxb5

38.axb5

We have a material imbalance resulting in equality.

38...Rb8 39.b6 Nxb6 40.cxb6 Qxb6 41.Qe1

Kramnik correctly decides to trade a pair of rooks.

41...Rec8 42.Rxc8+ Rxc8

The position is equal. One would expect White to give his king some air and play h3 or h4 now or on the next move, and then a draw agreement. However we are very far from the last miracle in this game!

43.Ng4 Re8 44.Bd3?!

Played with a wrong idea in mind.

44...Qd4

45.Be4?

This blunders a piece!

47.Bb1 Qb2 48.h4 Ra1 49.Kh2 Qxb1 50.Qxe5 Qh1+ 51.Kg3 Qe1+ 52.Qxe1 Rxe1

We have reached a theoretically drawn ending. But many mistakes will still be made and there is a lot to learn from this ending! This is, however, not an endgame book, so I will only point out a few important moments.

53.Kf4 Re2 54.Ne3 g6 55.g4 Kf7 56.h5 g5+

After 56...gxh5 57.gxh5 Rh2 58.Kg4 Black's h6-pawn is a target and White has an easy draw.

Ke5 65.Ng3 etc.

As a result of his active defence, White now has to take an important decision.

59.Nd5?

This desicion should have cost him the game.

knight coordinate well enough to hold.

59.fxg5 also held the draw, however after 59...hxg5 60.Nd5 Rf7 White has to
