Game 42 Bogdan-Daniel Deac 2693 Ray Robson 2689 Prague 2023 Modern theoretical/middlegame discussions in the Ruy Lopez Anti-Berlin variation are centred around White's attempt to prove that only the control of the open e-file is sufficient to put Black under long-term pressure. This game is a good example, and I will also put some other relevant examples in the comments. White tries to combine the control of the e-file, more space, and tactical elements, to put long-term pressure on Black. With precise play Black should be okay, but in human play it's easy to err. Also, in normal circustances, White has pressure while being on the safe side - Black rarely wins those positions, and this often puts White in a psychologically comfortable situation.

1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5 Nf6 4.O-O Nxe4 5.Re1 Nd6

6.Nxe5

Recently, White players have also tried 6.a4!?, which is based on a strategic idea: White tries to get a favourable pawn structure on the queenside after 6...a6 (6...Be7 is considered Black's best - see the next game, Grandelius-Howell) 7.Nxe5 Be7 8.Bf1 Nxe5 9.Rxe5 O-O 10.d4 and compared to our current main game we have the moves

6.a4 a6 included. This favours White in quite a number of lines, for example

10...Ne8 11.Nc3 Bf6 12.Re1 d5 13.a5 c6.

White's pawn being on a5 and Black's on a6 clearly favour White here as Black's queenside can be easier targeted. Grischuk achieved the same and got a nice advantage in his game vs Gukesh (see the comments to 13.Qc3!? in this game)!

6...Be7 7.Bf1 Nxe5 8.Rxe5 O-O 9.d4 Bf6 10.Re1

Though the pawn structure is symmetrical, White has some advantage. He has more space and easier development, and controls the only open file. Black aims to exchange a few pieces, finish development and equalize. In practical human vs human play, Black's road to equality is not exactly straightforward, as precision is needed and it is easy to err. We regularly see quite a number of top players stumbling on this road as Black.

10...Re8

At the moment of writing, the text is the most played move here. Black's plan is clear: trade a pair of rooks and finish development. Black's main alternative is 10...Nf5. Here, the most ambitious for White is to take space: 11.d5 Re8 (if Black starts with 11...d6, White plays 12.Nd2 and after 12...Re8

13.Ne4 the situation is not pleasant for Black as White has more space while Black

has problems to develop his cramped pieces) 12.Rxe8+ Qxe8 13.Qd3 d6 14.Nd2. An important moment! Black (Aronian) follows the logic: 'I have less space, let's trade some pieces'. It's sound logic but it doesn't work here. As I said, in human over-the-board play the road to equality is not easy as Black needs to be precise!

14...Bg5 (Black needed to hit White's centre to look for immediate activity with

14...c6! 15.c3 - very probably, Levon did not like 15.Ne4, but Black has suffient

dynamics for equality after 15...Be5! - 15...cxd5 16.Qxd5 Qc6! 17.Qxc6 bxc6

18.Ne4 Be7 and the position is equal; the game Jones-Jakovenko, Khanty-Mansiysk

2019, later ended in a draw) 15.Nf3 Bxc1 16.Rxc1 and Black has a difficult life ahead! White will control the e-file, and keep and increase his space advantage while Black struggles to find any counterplay: 16...Bd7 17.Re1 Qd8 18.Qc4. White's pieces are well coordinated, he has firm grip on the position, and counterplay with ...c6 will work less good now, e.g. 18...g6 19.h3 Ng7 20.Re3 a5

21.a4. It's not easy to give Black good advice, so Aronian says: 'Okay, I don't have

31.Qxg6 1-0 Carlsen-Aronian, Stavanger 2018.

11.Bf4 Rxe1 12.Qxe1 Ne8

Black's plan is clear: push ...d5, develop the Bc8, preferably trade a few more pieces and make a draw. White has different options, and he can choose between a technical and a tactical approach.

13.c3

A) The tactical option is 13.Nc3!?. White wants to build on his development advantage and does not mind sacrificing (a) pawn(s) in the process. We now get interesting tactical play where White is taking risks too. This has been tried in quite a few games at top level. The ensuing positions are probably dynamically balanced. For readers with a good memory who are willing to put in some serious computer- supported work, it can be rewarding. I will give a couple of interesting examples. The most principled decision, accepting the sacrifice, is Black's best here: 13...Bxd4! (White has a safe advantage after 13...d6 14.Bd3) 14.Nd5 and now: A1) 14...c6 leads more or less by force to a slight technical advantage for White:

15.Ne7+ Kf8 16.Nxc8 Qf6! 17.Rd1! Rxc8 18.Qe4

18...Bc5 19.Rxd7 Rd8 20.Rxd8 Qxd8. White has the bishop pair advantage and a

safe long-term pull. It does not hurt to mention that this is one of those typical positions where the bishop pair brings White an advantage while 'pure bishop vs knight' would be equal. In the few top games we have, White pressed a bit but ultimately it ended in a draw as in, for example, Dominguez Perez-So, Zagreb rapid 2022; A2) 14...d6 15.Bg5 f6 16.Bh4 (on the top level, White has also tried other moves here, like 16.Be3, 16.Qe4 or 16.Bc4) 16...g5! (16...Bxb2 is certainly playable; however, after 17.Rb1 Be5 18.f4

20.fxe5 dxe5 21.Bd3.

Black has collected some pawns but has a weak king. 14.Bd3 has been tried in a number of top games (including Carlsen-Karjakin during

15.Qe3 c6 16.Re1

White has pressure here, based on his control of the e-file. He will combine it with pushing his kingside pawns. Can Black equalize? Yes, probably. Is it easy? No. Your engine will give you close to zeroes but do not mistake this for 'easy equality'! Black needs to be precise and it is easy to err.

17...Bg5

White does control the e-file, but how to improve? Push the kingside pawns!

18.g4!

The alternative pushing idea is 18.Bxg5 Qxg5 19.f4 (19.g4 Qxe3! is fine for Black, as the queen trade brings him closer to equality here) 19...Qg6 20.g4 Nd6! with ...Re8 to follow - by pushing pawns White has also abandoned a few squares. Black should hold equality here, but in a game between humans, the position looks easier to play for White. The first question for Black is: should he still allow White to take Bxg5, changing the pawn structure, or not? Robson decides not to react.

36.g5! Ng8 37.Qh8 1-0

To prevent mate, Black will first lose his queen, and then some. Game 43 Nils Grandelius 2672 David Howell 2646 London ENG-SWE Challenge Match 2022

1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5 Nf6 4.O-O Nxe4 5.Re1 Nd6 6.a4!?

As I explained in the comments to the game Deac-Robson, this line, which is still considered to be a relative sideline, has a strategic idea behind it. White hopes that Black will push 6...a6, when he will get a strategically favourable version of the main 6.Ne5 lines. David Howell ignores White and continues developing:

6...Be7

White's positional idea behind 6.a4!? becomes clear in the following continuation:

6...a6 7.Nxe5 Be7 8.Bf1

A) If Black plays 8...O-O, White takes space with 9.d4 Nf5 and here White has a choice between playing for a positional advantage or making an interesting pawn sacrifice. A1) With his development advantage and control of the e-file, White has interesting tactical ideas like the pawn sacrifice 10.Nc3!? Ncxd4 analysis diagram

11.Nd5 (11.g4? is not a piece win due to (simple) 11...Nh4 12.Qxd4 d6). White has

dynamic piece play and Black needs to be careful: 11...Bc5! 12.Nd3 Ba7 13.Qg4 (White has serious threats like 14.c3 or 14.Bg5) 13...Qh4! (13...d6? runs into the textbook tactic 14.Bg5 f6 15.Bxf6! Rxf6 16.Re8+) 14.Qxh4 Nxh4 15.Nxc7 Rb8. The smoke is slowly starting to clear; White does not have more than an a tiny advantage after 16.Be3 (playing for 'domination' with the inspired 16.Bf4 Nxc2 17.Bd6!? Nxe1

18.Rxe1 leads to equality after 18...g6! 19.Nd5 Nf5 and we will probably have a

peaceful outcome; for example, 20.Nf6+ Kg7 21.Bxf8+ Kxf8 22.Ne5 Kg7 23.Ne8+ Kf8 24.Nf6 Kg7) 16...Nhf5 17.Bxd4 Nxd4 18.Nb4 d6; A2) 10.d5 leads to a positional advantage after 10...Nxe5 11.Rxe5 d6 12.Re1 - compare this to the game Carlsen-Aronian (in the comments to Deac-Robson), White has a similar kind of pull here; A3) Another safe road to a small advantage for White is 10.Nf3 d5 11.c3. In general, Black would prefer to have some of the light pieces already traded in positions like these. B) 8...Nxe5 9.Rxe5 O-O 10.d4 Ne8 11.Nc3 Bf6 12.Re1 d5 13.a5!. The advantages White gets by the inclusion of 6.a4 a6 are becoming clear. White will have an advantage on the queenside, where the pawn structure is fixed, plus regular e-file pressure and kingside attack ideas. 13...c6 14.Bf4. B1) Now Aronian, playing Black, went for a standard bishop trade: 14...Bg5 15.Be5 Bf6 16.Qd2 Bxe5 17.Rxe5. White has a good situation here: e-file control, a nice outpost for his knight on the queenside (on c5), and the option to push his kingside pawns like in Deac-Robson. Also, we can compare this position to Grischuk-Gukesh from the comments to Deac- Robson: White has similar trumps here. After 17...Nf6 18.f3 Be6 19.Na4 Qd6 20.b4 Nd7 21.Re3 Rae8 22.Rae1 Black was doomed to passive defence but managed to survive to a draw in Niemann-Aronian, Saint Louis 2022; B2) The silicon brain suggests a radical solution to the problem: 14...b5!?, which is definitely not an easy decision for a human player. White should opt for a pawn sacrifice: 15.axb6! Qxb6 analysis diagram

16.Na4! (another option is 16.Bd3 Bxd4 17.Qd2 when White definitely has

compensation but perhaps not more) 16...Qxd4 17.Qf3 Qa7 18.c3. Black has won a pawn, but his Ne8 is badly placed, the a6-pawn is weak, and his piece coordination is not good. White will play b4 followed by Nc5 and despite the pawn he has better chances here.

7.Nc3 O-O 8.d4!

White has a development advantage and wants to keep the momentum.

8...Nxd4!?

Black accepts the challenge! A huge majority of top players decided on the relatively boring 8...e4 when we get a standard small plus for White after 9.Nxe4 Nxe4

10.Rxe4.

9.Nxd4 exd4 10.Nd5

Due to his development advantage, White has a strong initiative and Black needs to be careful - the price of each move here is high!

10...Re8?

This logical move is a mistake that should have been (almost) losing. Black's best is 10...Bh4!, but this is just the first in a series of accurate moves Black needs to play to keep the balance. Now the move that puts Black most to the test is

11.Bd3 (11.g3 c6 12.gxh4 cxd5! leads to equality, while 12...cxb5?? is a losing

blunder due to 13.Bg5 f6 14.Bf4). A) Pushing a pawn with tempo is usually a good idea in such situations, but here

11...c6 is a losing blunder due to 12.Nc7! and Black's position can no longer be

saved! 12...Qxc7 (12...Rb8? loses prosaically to 13.Bf4 Be7 14.Qe2) 13.Qh5! Bxf2+

14.Kxf2 and Black is three pawns up but cannot develop. One recent GM-level game

continued 14...f5 (14...g6 does not change much; White has various roads to victory here: 15.Qh4 Ne8 16.Bh6 Ng7 17.Re7 and Black's king is too weak while he cannot develop the queenside, giving White plenty of time for the kill) 15.Re7 Ne4+. Now White executes nicely: 16.Kg1! Qd8

17.Rxe4! g6 18.Rg4! fxg4 19.Bxg6 hxg6 (19...Qe7 loses to 20.Bh6 Rf6 - precision

is always important as White has only one way to win here: 21.Bxh7+!) 20.Qxg6+ Kh8. Here White has several wins, but he considers that grabbing a free extra pawn does not hurt: 21.Qh5+ Kg8 22.Qxg4+ Kh7 23.Qh5+ Kg8 24.Qg6+ Kh8 25.Bg5 Qa5

26.Rf1 Rxf1+ 27.Kxf1 1-0 Balakrishnan-Quesada Perez, Chesterfield 2022;

B) Black has only one move to keep the balance: 11...b6! 12.Qg4. Now Black needs another smart move: 12...f5! (12...Bb7? loses to 13.Bh6 Bf6 14.Nxf6+ Qxf6 15.Bg5 and Black's queen is trapped) 13.Qxd4 Bb7 14.Bf4 Ne4. The position is still sharp, but Black should hold the balance.

11.Qg4

Black's problem is his undeveloped queenside. White's development advantage is simply too big here.

11...f5

11...c6! is perhaps the most resilient here, however after 12.Bh6 g6 (12...Bf6 loses to

13.Nxf6+ Qxf6 14.Bg5 Qg6 15.Bd3 f5 16.Qxd4) 13.Nxe7+ Rxe7 14.Bd3 Ne8

15.Qxd4 ...

analysis diagram Black has indeed avoided an immediate annihilation, but his situation is far from good, for example 15...d6 16.Bg5 (16.h4 also looks promising) 16...f6 17.Bd2 and with h2-h4-h5 to follow White has plenty of compensation here, as Black's king is weak while his pieces still coordinate poorly.

12.Qxd4 Bf6

12...c6 now loses to 13.Nxe7+ Rxe7 14.Bg5 and the end picture after 14...Rxe1+

15.Rxe1 Qxg5 16.Qxd6 perfectly illustrates Black's poor development.

13.Nxf6+ Qxf6 14.Bc4+! Kh8 15.Rxe8+ Nxe8

Black has escaped an immediate slaughter, but his queenside is still not developed. White has a winning advantage but, of course, precision is needed! Grandelius lets it slip:

16.Qe3

White should have realised how huge his development is (and it is not diminished after a queen trade) and should have gone for the strong and precise 16.Be3!. Black has to try to develop: 16...d6 (16...c6 loses to 17.Re1 d5 18.Bg5! Qf8 analysis diagram

19.Qc5 Qg8 20.Bd3 - Black cannot develop and will soon lose decisive material; in

Stockfish language this position is plus four). Now White calmly brings on his rook to penetrate the e-file: 17.Re1!. Black has to trade queens: 17...Qxd4 (17...Bd7 loses to 18.Qd5! Qf8 19.Qxb7) 18.Bxd4 Bd7 19.Re7 (White has total domination)

19...Bxa4 (on 19...Rd8, White calmly keeps improving his position with 20.h4)

24.Bf7+ Kh7 25.Bxe8. Black's ordeal is far from over as 26.Bg6+ is to come, so

Black will lose his rook too.

16...Qf8 17.b3

White is still better, but Black now has objective survival chances.

17...Nf6 18.Bb2 d5! 19.Bd3 c5

19...Bd7 was perhaps a better defence.

20.Bxf6 gxf6

21.Qf3

White misses the last chance to make Black's life difficult. Precise was 21.Re1 Bd7

22.Qf4! and Black is still far from a draw as 22...Re8? loses to 23.Rxe8 Qxe8

24.Qd6 or 23...Bxe8 24.Qxf5.

21...Be6 22.Bxf5 Bg8! 23.Re1 Re8 24.Rxe8 Qxe8

White does not have enough material to take advantage of Black's weak king.

25.h4 Qe1+ 26.Kh2 Qe5+ 27.g3 d4 28.Bd3 Bd5 29.Qg4 Be6 30.Qf3 Bd5 31.Qg4

Be6 32.Qf3 Bd5 1⁄2-1⁄2 Game 44 Rasmus Svane 2594 Luke McShane 2675 Germany Bundesliga 2019/20

1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5 Nf6 4.O-O Nxe4 5.Re1 Nd6 6.Nxe5 Be7 7.Bf1 Nxe5

8.Rxe5 O-O 9.d4 Bf6 10.Re2!?

This rook retreat is considerably less often played than the main line 10.Re1, but there is definitely logic behind it. White steers the game into slightly different directions as now Black reacts differently.

10...b6

Let's first try to understand the difference with the 10. Re1 retreat. Should Black stick to the same plan and continue 10...Re8, then the rook on e2 offers White a number of advantages because if Black captures ...Rxe2 and White recaptures Qxe2, White's queen will be considerably better placed on e2 than on e1. White has two ways to try to take advantage of this situation: A) 11.Bf4 Rxe2 12.Qxe2. Black is not forced to accept White's pawn sacrifice here, but then White has a risk-free advantage: 12...Bxd4. White has different options (move-orders) here, perhaps the most precise being 13.Bxd6 cxd6 14.Na3. analysis diagram Black needs to try to develop with 14...d5! (grabbing another pawn loses too much time: 14...Bxb2? 15.Re1 Qf8 16.Nb5 - Black cannot complete his development and White soon wins decisive material, e.g. 16...Bf6 17.Nc7 Rb8 18.Qb5! Be7 19.Re3! b6 20.Qe2) 15.Re1 Qf8 16.Nb5 Bb6 17.Nc3! Ba5 18.Qb5 Bxc3 19.bxc3. White gets his pawn back, and Black still needs to develop his queenside, so his problems are not solved yet; B) Another way for White to obtain an edge is 11.c3 and after 11...Rxe2 (we can also use the move-order 11...Nf5 12.Bf4 Rxe2 - not 12...c6?? as with White's rook on e2 instead of e1, this loses on the spot to the simple 13.Bc7! - 13.Qxe2) 12.Qxe2. White's queen being on e2 instead of e1 brings White a couple of advantages: his rook can move directly to e1, exerting immediate e-file pressure, the queen can move to f3 and also White sometimes has Qb5 ideas. For example: B1) If 12...Ne8, White can now take space similar to Carlsen-Aronian (see the comments to Deac-Robson): 13.d5 (another option is 13.Bf4 d5 14.Nd2 and now in case of 14...Bf5 we see the advantage of the queen being on e2: 15.Qb5!) 13...c6 and now it comes in handy for White to have 14.Qf3!, with an advantage in Kovalenko- Omelja, Bialystok 2017; B2) 12...Nf5 13.Bf4 c6. Now White has a good option in 14.g4! Nh4 - thanks to the queen being on e2, this knight jump does not pose any threat, so White can calmly continue 15.Bd6. C) The pawn sacrifice 11.Nc3 is more of a rapid play weapon as Black is fine after

11...Rxe2 12.Qxe2.

Black has to accept the sacrifice: 12...Bxd4! (12...Qe8 leads to an inferior ending for Black after 13.Nd5 Bd8 14.Qf3 Qe4 15.Qxe4 Nxe4 16.Bf4 c6 17.Nc7 Bxc7 18.Bxc7 d5 19.f3 and due to his bishop pair, White had a clear advantage and went on to win in Hansen-Hammer, PRO League rapid 2017) 13.Nd5 c6. Now, White has different ways to get sufficient compensation, but not more: C1) On 14.Bf4, a tactical resource keeps the balance: 14...Bxf2+! 15.Qxf2 Ne4

16.Qd4 cxd5;

C2) Or 14.Ne7+ Kf8 and White has many ideas but nothing substantial, e.g. 15.Bg5 (15.Bf4 Ne8!) 15...f6 16.Nxc8 Rxc8 17.Qd3 Qb6; C3) 14.Nc7 Qxc7 15.Bf4 b6. Now, to keep the momentum, it makes sense for White to sacrifice another pawn: 16.Rd1! (16.c3 looks about equal after 16...Bf6 17.Rd1 Bb7) 16...Bxb2 17.Bxd6 Qd8. White has great domination, but the silicon brain gives zeroes... in human play this can be unpeasant for Black. With the text, Black wants to play ...Ba6 followed by a trade of the light-squared bishops.

11.Re1

McShane first trades a pair of rooks and then develops his Bc8 - probably not the most precise order.

11...Re8

A more accurate development is 11...Bb7. We have a number of top-level games here, most of which end in draws. I would like to explore one a bit further: 12.a4!?. The next few moves are logical: 12...Bg5 13.Nc3 Bxc1 14.Qxc1 Qf6 15.Qd2. An important moment! Black continues his 'trading plan' but this allows White to get an edge: 15...Rae8 (it was better to stop White's a-pawn advance with 15...a5!. David Navara most likely refrained from this decision because he did not like his position after 16.Re5 Rae8 17.Rae1. But Black is able to neutralize White's e-file pressure and equalize with 17...Re6! 18.Nb5 Nxb5 19.Bxb5 and now the 'dynamic defense' 19...Rfe8! 20.Qc3 Rxe5 21.dxe5 Qg6 22.f3 Bc6 with equality) 16.a5!. Now White has an edge. Black continues his 'trading plan': 16...Ne4 17.Nxe4 Rxe4

18.Rxe4 Bxe4 19.Re1 Bf5 20.Qf4 d6.

White has an advantage here, but probably Grandelius did not get the most out of the position. Most precise looks 21.a6! - the e-file is important here! Endings will be unpleasant for Black, for example 21...Be6 22.Qxf6 gxf6 23.Bb5 and Black faces a difficult time (e-file, structural problems, space...). The game went 21.c3 Be6

22.Qxf6 gxf6 and White had an advantage but Black managed to survive in

Grandelius-Navara, Malmö 2022.

12.Bf4 Rxe1 13.Qxe1

A pair of rooks has been traded. Black faces problems similar to other examples in this chapter: White's e-file pressure, space, and Black's bishop on b7 will be passive too. Can Black equalize? Perhaps, but, as in several other examples in this chapter, though the silicon brain evaluates at close to zero, it's not easy in practical human play.

13...Ne8 14.Nc3 Bb7 15.Qd2 d5 16.Re1 Nd6

The counterplay attempt 16...c5 does not bring Black equality after 17.dxc5 bxc5. analysis diagram Due to the badly placed Ne8, this position with hanging pawns in the centre favours White. A) The easy positional way is 18.g3; Black needs to react and White has an advantage after 18...d4 19.Ne4 Be7 20.Bg2 Qb6 21.b3; B) White can also opt for more direct play with 18.Na4 Rc8 (this allows a tactical solution; the alternative 18...c4 also leads to White's advantage after 19.Nc3)

19.Nxc5! Rxc5 20.Qb4 Rxc2 21.Qxb7 and Black's best way to stay in the game is to

25.Re2 Bb6 26.Rd2 Rc8 27.g3 and Black will struggle for a draw.

17.Bd3

Black goes for immediate counterplay, allowing a nice tactical idea:

17...c5

Changing the central pawn structure with 17...Nc4 18.Bxc4 dxc4 19.Be5 leads to positions that look pleasant for White to me due to the well-placed Nc3 and Black's doubled c-pawns. Probably McShane was thinking the same, but my Stockfish gives close to zeros after 19...Bxe5 20.Rxe5 h6 or immediately 19...h6. An interesting idea was 17...Bxd4!? 18.Bxh7+ Kxh7 19.Qxd4 Kg8. White spots the tactical solution!

18.dxc5! bxc5 19.Nxd5! Bxd5 20.Bxh7+ Kxh7 21.Qxd5

Black is still very much in the game, but precise defense is needed.

21...Be7

A) If 21...Nb5, White grabs a third pawn with 22.Qxf7 and Black's king is weak. After the arguably best 22...Rc8, 23.c3 is better for White, and 22...Bxb2? blunders a piece to 23.Qf5+ Kg8 24.Qe6+ Kh8 25.Qh3+ Kg8 26.Qb3+; B) 21...Ne8 22.Qxf7 Bxb2 does not work for Black due to his weak king: 23.Qh5+ Kg8 24.Rd1 Qc8 25.Qd5+ Kh7 (25...Kh8 loses to 26.Rd3). White has a winning advantage but he still needs to take care: 26.Qe4+! (on 26.Rd3? Black has 26...Nf6!)

26...Kh8 (or 26...Kg8 27.Rd3). Now, with Black's king on the eighth rank, 27.Rd3

21...Qa5 was a good defensive resource, e.g. 22.c3

22...Re8! 23.Rxe8 Nxe8 24.Qe4+ g6 25.Qxe8 Qxa2 - it's not easy to say, but Black

might be closer to a draw than White to a win here. Now White allows Black to escape:

22.Re3

White missed a nice solution with 22.Kf1!. White king is no longer threatened by a back rank mate, while also it will be hiding from checks. Black's best is 22...Rc8 (22...Rb8 loses to 23.Rxe7 Qxe7 24.Bxd6; 22...Kg8 runs into 23.Rxe7) 23.Bxd6 Bxd6 24.Rd1 Qf6 25.Qxd6 Qxb2 26.Qd3+. Now that the smoke has cleared, White is a pawn up in a technical endgame.

22.Bxd6 Bxd6 23.Rd1 leads to a draw after 23...Rb8 24.Qxd6 Qxd6 25.Rxd6 Rxb2.

22...Bf8

This move does not lose, but it forces Black to find a difficult defensive resource a few moves down the road.

23.Rh3+ Kg8 24.Qh5 f6 25.Qh8+ Kf7 26.Qh5+ Kg8 27.g4!

White correctly decides to play on and put Black to the test!

27...Qe8?

The losing mistake. To stay in the game, Black had to come up with a difficult-to- find defensive resource: 27...c4! 28.g5 Qa5!. Black's queen is active and White's king is exposed - Black saves the game! 36.Re5! 1-0

A typical Ruy Lopez Breyer position Diagrammed is a typical Ruy Lopez position. This particular position comes from the Breyer Variation but we may get something similar from other closed Ruy Lopez variations. Black has a well-placed knight on the c5-outpost, while White has almost everything else. Many great players, Magnus Carlsen included, have opted for this position as Black. I have some experience with it, and I did not like it because White has different plans while Black does not have clear and easy to execute counterplay. One of White's main plans is to open up the kingside and get an attack there by pushing his f-pawn to f4. The selected game and those included in the comments show White's plans and the problems Black faces in these positions. The f4 push in a closed centre Game 45 Maxime Vachier-Lagrave 2780 Bassem Amin 2704 France tt 2019 In this game I will show a typical type of position coming from the Breyer Variation - as said, similar positions may come from other classical Ruy Lopez variations. The central structure is fixed, Black's knight is (sort of) well placed on c5, while White has many other things! White's main plan is to push the f-pawn to f4, opening up the kingside to get an attack. As a consequence, Black will get a central outpost on e5 (usually for a knight) but nevertheless Black struggles to find active counterplay. I never felt comfortable in such situations as Black and ended up playing a different type of Breyer where the central structure was not fixed with 15...c5 16.d5 c4. This game, and a number of examples given in the comments, illustrate well the kind of problem Black faces or may easily face.

1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5 a6 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.O-O Be7 6.Re1 b5 7.Bb3 d6 8.c3 O-O 9.h3

Nb8 10.d4 Nbd7 11.Nbd2 Bb7 12.Bc2 Re8 13.Nf1 Bf8 14.Ng3 g6 15.a4 c5 An important strategic decision, fixing the pawn structure. Black does not have to do this - he can keep the central pawn structure fluid and opt for other main lines here, like for example 15...Bg7.

16.d5 c4 17.Bg5

A typical pawn structure in this line. Black is happy getting his knight to c5, White is preparing a kingside attack, mostly introduced by the with f4 push. White has more space and can combine kingside and queenside plans, as he does in this game. Black's Bb7 often turns out passive, while it is strategically clever for him to trade off his dark-squared bishop - but on the other hand, that bishop protects his king. This strategically complex position has been played in many top-level games. I am personally not really fond of Black's strategy and after years of experience, I think that with this fixed central structure we have to favour White here, primarily due to his space advantage and the options to play on both sides of the board. Let's see how the play develops.

17...Nc5

Black can also place his knight on c5 in a slightly different version: 17...h6 18.Be3 Nc5 and now: A) 19.Qd2 h5 and now: A1) You may wonder what happens if White changes the pawn structure and doubles Black's pawns with 20.Bxc5 dxc5. We have some top-level games here. Yes, White did double Black's pawns, but he has also parted with his bishop pair. White has somewhat better chances. I like the following idea Anish Giri demonstrated in a blitz game: 21.Qe3 Rb8 (White's area of action will be the queenside) 22.Nf1 Bc8 23.N1d2 Bd7 24.axb5 axb5 25.Ra6. Black needs to worry about a timely b3-pawn push by White: 25...Rb6 26.Ra7 Qb8 27.Rea1 Qd6. White is doing great, Anish comes up with a nice idea: 28.Bd1! (28.b3 also leads to White's advantage as the queenside is favourably opened for him after 28...cxb3

29.Bxb3 with 30.c4 to follow and if 30...b4, 31.Ba4 with a favourable bishops trade)

28...Bg7 29.Be2! Reb8 30.Bxc4! (game over!) 30...bxc4 31.Nxc4 Qe7 32.Nxb6

Rxb6 33.b4 Bf8 34.R7a5 Bb5 35.bxc5 Qxc5 36.Qxc5 Bxc5 37.c4 Nxe4 38.Rxb5 and White won easily in Giri-Karjakin, Flor & Fjaere 2014; A2) 20.Bg5. Now where to place black bishop is not an easy choice: 20...Bg7 (20...Be7 is the alternative) 21.Rf1! (White is getting ready to push the f-pawn)

21...Qc7 22.Bh6. Fabiano Caruana faces an unpleasant dilemma: to trade or not to

trade? Both decision do not really look good for Black: 22...Bh8. White now had the right idea, but did not get it done in a precise way:

23.Ng5 (strongest was 23.Nh4!, for example 23...bxa4 24.f4! exf4 25.Rxf4 and

White has a winning attack. In Stockfish language, this is close to plus two) and now: A21) Black's best chance to get counterplay was by timely disturbing White's Ng3 with 23...h4! when after 24.Ne2 bxa4 25.f4 analysis diagram Black does not react in the centre but plays 25...Rab8!. White now struggles to get his attack going: 26.f5 Bc8! 27.Rab1 and here it is clever to trade a pair of rooks (fewer potential attackers, less headache!) 27...a3! 28.bxa3 Rxb1 29.Bxb1. analysis diagram Black's king is safe here, so now he can force the strategically good trade 29...Bg7! with a good game; A22) 23...Nh7 24.Nxh7 (the immediate 24.f4 was strong too) 24...Kxh7 25.Be3 Qe7

26.f4! (it is important to have both rooks on the board as f-file pressure is essential

for a successful attack here) 26...exf4 27.Bxf4 (27.Rxf4 was perhaps even stronger:

27...Be5 28.Raf1!.

analysis diagram A standard situation - Black's king is weak, the Bb7 is out of play, the Nc5 is standing there nicely and doing more or less nothing: 28...Bxf4 29.Rxf4 Nd7

30.Nxh5! and White wins after 30...gxh5 31.Qd1 or 30...Rh8 31.Qf2) 27...Kg8. Now

White doubles on the f-file, so having both rooks on the board is important here:

28.Rf3 Bg7 29.Raf1 Nd7.

Now White traded off the defender with 30.Bh6! Bxh6 31.Qxh6 Qf8 32.Qd2 (32.Nf5 was more efficient) 32...Ne5 33.Rf6 and we have a typical situation. Black has a nice knight on e5, while White has everything else. The knight on the e5-outpost is not enough to hold Black's position. White went on to win in Zherebukh-Caruana, Saint Louis 2017. You may wonder what Fabiano did wrong to get into such trouble? Actually, not much. The position is simply easier to play for White and it is easy for Black to get into terrible trouble. The game we are following was a classical time limit game in the United States Championships. B) White can also play slightly differently, though following a similar plan, with

19.Kh1!? (White plans to push f4 later on and places his king on a better square)

19...Rb8 20.Qd2 h5 21.axb5 axb5

22.Ng5! White is now ready for the f-pawn push: 22...Bg7 23.f4! exf4 24.Bxf4. As

already seen, most of the time Black's counterplay idea in these positions is to timely disturb White's Ng3 and this is what Short, playing Black, does now: 24...h4 25.Nf1 Nh5 26.Be3 Bf6. It looks as if Black has sufficient tactical resources as White's king on h1 can now also come under check. How should White continue? 27.Nh2! Bc8 (the pawn grab

27...Ng3+ is not a good idea here as White develops a strong attack after 28.Kg1

Ncxe4 29.Nxe4 Nxe4 30.Bxe4 Rxe4 31.Ng4: analysis diagram

31...Bg7 32.Ba7! Rxe1+ 33.Rxe1 Ra8 34.Bd4 and Black's king has no defenders, his

Bb7, Ra8 are out of play - actually a typical situation in this line; White has a winning attack) 28.Nhf3 (White has the right idea, but he could have executed it in a better way. Pro-actively removing the king from check first with 28.Kg1! was strong here. You may wonder, after Black's knight jump to g3, what difference does it make? 28...Ng3. analysis diagram Well, it does as White now has a nice tactic: 29.Nxf7! Kxf7 30.Bxc5 dxc5 31.Nf3 and since the e-pawn push is coming, Black will have to give some material back, White has a clear advantage) 28...Ng3+ 29.Kh2 Ncxe4 30.Nxe4 Nxe4 31.Bxe4 Rxe4

32.Ba7! (White did not want to get greedy with 32.Bb6 Qxb6 33.Rxe4 Bf5 when

Black would have some compensation for the exchange) 32...Rxe1 33.Rxe1 Ra8

34.Bd4. White has a promising attack. Black's king is weak, his Ra8 is out of play,

his Bc8 is not doing much and his pawn on h4 is likely to fall... still, Black managed to survive to a draw in Stellwagen-Short, Hoogeveen 2004.

18.Nh2

White can also play a bit differently. Executing a simlar plan starting with 18.Qd2 also looks promising. The Nf3 will move and the f-pawn push will come. A few top games went 18...Be7 19.Bh6 Nfd7. Black's queenside counterplay is rather slow and White can quickly develop a promising attack: A) 20.Nh2 and now: bxa4 A1) In case of 20...Nxa4, the following variation illustrates how easily things can go wrong for Black: 21.Ng4!? (White can of course opt for 21.Bxa4 bxa4 22.Rxa4 a5

23.Be3 with an advantage - here he can combine queenside play with the f-pawn

push) 21...Nxb2. Black is now two pawns up, and White starts action: 22.f4 Bh4 (White has a promising attack, minimally worth the sacrificed material, after

22...exf4 23.Qxf4) 23.Bg5! Bxg5 24.fxg5 Rf8 25.Rf1. Now Black has to react:

25...f6 26.gxf6 Nxf6 27.Nh6+ Kh8 (again, the f-file is important; having both rooks

on the board is essential for White's attack) 28.Rf3 Qe7 29.Raf1. Black cannot hold his kingside, this position is plus three according to Stockfish! It's very easy for Black to get into trouble in these positions!; A2) If 20...bxa4, White goes for the attack with 21.Ng4 (21.Bxa4 also leads to White's advantage) 21...Nb3 22.Bxb3 axb3

23.f4! Black's Bb7 is a 'dead piece'. 23...Nf6. Here, strongest for White was 24.Rf1

with an attack that should have resulted in a full point. The game went 24.Ne3 exf4

25.Bxf4 and White had an advantage but Black survived to a draw in Borisek-Amin,

Batumi 2018. B) Starting off with 20.Rf1 with Nh2 and f4 to follow is fine for White too; C) An example of 'non principled play' by White was seen some years ago at the Qatar masters (with a classical time limit): 20.a5 Bc8!. Now White placed both of his rooks on passive positions because was overly concerned about losing his a-pawn:

21.Ra3? Nb7 22.Rea1 Ndc5. Now White wants to attack, but without rooks it does

not work the same way: 23.Nh2 Bd7 24.Be3 Bh4. Despite placing both his rooks in passive positions, White's worries about the a5-pawn are not over as Black can play ...Na4 and still collect that pawn. Black easily won in Mista-Giri, Doha 2014;

18...h6 19.Be3 h5 20.Qf3 Nh7 21.Qe2 Qc7

Retreating the knight with 21...Nf6 is not an easy move to make but it would have stopped the development in the game.

22.Ngf1!

A strong move! The knight goes to d2 when: a) after the f4 push, the move ...h4 can never disturb White; and b) Black also needs to worry about a timely b4 or b3 pawn push, opening up the queenside.

22...Rab8 23.Nd2 Bc8

23...Nf6 24.Rf1 Bg7 is aimed against the immediate f-pawn push, but White gets the

upper hand with 25.Nhf3 (White wants to play 26.Ng5 followed by f4) 25...Nh7 and now White can switch to queenside action: 26.Ra3 Bc8 27.axb5 axb5 analysis diagram

28.b4! cxb3 29.Nxb3 and Black is in trouble on the queenside: 29...Na4 30.c4 with a

strong initiative.

24.axb5 axb5

MVL correctly feels the time is right!

25.f4! exf4 26.Bxf4 Nf6 27.Qf1!

Well played! 27.Qf2 may look more logical, but after 27...b4! Black's c4-pawn is not hanging.

27...Nfd7

Now after 27...b4 28.Nhf3 (28.Qxc4?! is premature and throws away the advantage after 28...Ba6 29.Rxa6 Nxa6 30.Qxa6 bxc3 31.bxc3 Nxd5) 28...bxc3 29.bxc3 Black's c4-pawn is weak and Black does not have a good way to solve this problem:

29...Rb2 30.Nd4 and the attempt to get counterplay with an exchange sacrifice does

not really work due to 30...Rxc2 31.Nxc2 Ncxe4 (31...Nfxe4? loses to 32.Qxc4)

32.Be3. White stands clearly better here.

28.Nhf3 Bg7

29.Qf2!

White's queen goes to a better square, preparing a doubling on the f-file double. Trading a pair of rooks is in general a good idea for Black (in similar positions) and this is what Bassem now does:

29...Rb6 30.Be3!

Moving the bishop from f4 to d4 is a standard plan for White in such positions!

30...Ra6 31.Rxa6 Bxa6 32.Bd4 Bf8

Black wants to keep the defender and retreats his bishop.

32...Ne5 does not solve Black's problems as White is clearly better after 33.Nxe5!

34...Bxd4 35.cxd4 Nd3 36.Bxd3 cxd3 37.Qd2.

33.Rf1 Bh6

A swift execution - damaging the opponent's king defences! The silicon brain points out that 34.Ng5 f6 35.e5! dxe5 36.Bxg6 works as well.

34...hxg4 35.Qh4 gxf3 36.Qxh6

A standard situation: Black's king is weak, his Ba6 is out of play and the Nc5 is standing nicely doing nothing.

36...Ne5 37.Nxf3 Ncd7 38.Ng5 Nf8

39.Nxf7! Qxf7 40.Rxf7 Kxf7

Black cannot build a fortress here.

41.Bd1! Re7

42.Bg4 1-0

A typical Ruy Lopez piece sacrifice in the centre This position, coming from a recent game, shows a typical piece sacrifice idea available to Black in many closed Ruy Lopez positions. I have tried similar sacrifices as Black and can advise you to explore these ideas. Black sacrifices a piece (usually a knight) to eliminate White's pawn centre. Black gets active play and his mobile pawn centre fully compensates for the sacrificed piece. Game 46 Arthur Pijpers 2465 Max Warmerdam 2602 Utrecht ch-NED 2023 I definitely wanted to include the type of sacrifice described above in this book, but I was looking for a fresh example. Help came from Max Warmerdam, who messaged me while I was writing: 'Hey Ivan, remember the sacrifice idea you were showing us at the Papendal (Dutch Olympic Centre) training last November? I played the same idea in my game yesterday! Have a look!'. Well, I did have a look and indeed - thank you Max, I like the game!

1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5 a6 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.O-O Be7 6.Re1 b5 7.Bb3 d6 8.c3 O-O 9.h3

Bb7 10.d4 Re8 11.a3 Less played than 11.Nbd2, but definitely also seen at top level.

11...h6

12.Ba2

There is a positional idea behind this bishop retreat. After pushing 13.d5, White wants to be able to build a pawn chain by playing b3 followed by c4.

12...Bf8

And now indeed White goes on to execute his strategic idea:

13.d5

Where to go with the knight?

13...Ne7

I think this is the best option. A) After 13...Nb8, Shirov, playing White, decided to keep the centre dynamic with

14.c4 (White should have some advantage by building the pawn chain with 14.b3 c6

15.c4) 14...c6. Shirov insists on keeping the centre dynamic: 15.Nc3 bxc4 16.dxc6

Bxc6 (16...Nxc6 was the alternative so as after 17.Bxc4 playing the dynamic

17...Nd4!.

analysis diagram White has some advantage though after 18.Nxd4 exd4 19.Qxd4 d5 20.Bf1 dxe4

21.Be3) 17.Bxc4 Qc7 (17...Nbd7 was better). Shirov does not need a further

invitation and goes for a direct attack! 18.Nh4! Bd7 and now comes a piece sac, the point of the previous move: 19.Nd5! Qxc4 20.Nxf6+ gxf6 21.Qh5. A1) If 21...Kh7, White wins by force with a beautiful variation: 22.b3! (the less forcing 22.Bd2 should bring White success as well) 22...Qxb3 23.Bxh6! Bxh6 analysis diagram

24.Reb1! (Black's queen has to defend the f7-pawn but cannot retreat to e6 due to

the Nf5 jump) 24...Qc4 25.Rb4! Qc3 26.Qxf7+ Bg7. What now? White is two pieces down while the Ra1 hangs with check. 27.Nf5! Qxa1+ 28.Kh2 Bxf5 29.exf5 and White wins, e.g. 29...e4 30.Qg6+ Kg8 31.Qxe8+ etc.; A2) Black played 21...f5 and now the great attacker Shirov missed the strongest continuation: 22.exf5! (the game itself went 22.Bxh6 Bxh6 23.Qxh6 f4 and White emerged victorious in Shirov-Erdös, Terme Catez Ech-tt 2021). The problem is that after 22...Be7 White now needs a strong follow-up: 23.Ng6!. Now Black has to give his extra piece back: 23...Nc6 24.Bxh6 Bxf5 25.Qxf5 Qe6 26.Qxe6 fxe6 27.Nxe7+ Rxe7 28.Rac1 and White is a sound pawn up in a technically won endgame. B) 13...Na7 leads to an easy and typical positional advantage for White after 14.b3 c5 15.c4. White gets a typical safe space advantage: 15...a5 16.a4 b4 17.Nbd2 Nc8 18.Bb1 Ne7 19.Nf1 Ng6 20.Ra2 and Black has no counterplay. He had to struggle for a draw in Ter Sahakyan-Azarov, Sharjah 2022.

14.b3

White sticks to his strategic idea of building a central pawn chain. Playing like Shirov in the comment above does not produce same result as Black's knight is now well placed on e7: 14.c4 c6 15.Nc3 bxc4 16.dxc6 Bxc6 17.Bxc4 Qc7 with equality, e.g. 18.Qb3 Ng6.

14...c6

If 14...c5, White gets an easy advantage with 15.c4! bxc4 16.bxc4 Ng6

17.Bb3! Bc8 18.Ba4 Bd7 19.Nc3. White has a favourable version of the Czech

Benoni, but it was a rapid game and Black later turned things around and even won in Firouzja-Le Quang Liem, Chessable Masters rapid 2021.

15.c4 cxd5 16.cxd5

A critical position! White wants to stabilize the queenside, in the ideal world by pushing 17.b4, and will be having a long-term positional advantage. Max comes up with a very interesting idea, first sacrificing a pawn to sentence White's Ba2 to death, and then sacrificing a piece to remove White's pawn centre, getting dynamic pawns of his own. Black will get only a pawn for his the piece, but White's pieces will coordinate poorly.

[diagram]
16...a5 was tried before. White continues 17.Nc3 b4 18.Nb5 Qb8 19.a4. White's B

will not stay on a2 forever, it will quickly be improved by Ba2-b1-d3, and White has the advantage here. The immediate sacrifice 16...Nxe4? does not work as the Ba2 is not 'killed' and White has a clear advantage after 17.Rxe4 Nxd5 18.b4! - the most human way.

17.axb4

The silicon brain understands the problem of the passive Ba2 and intially suggests

Black should play aggressively: 19...g5!. 17...Nxe4! 18.Rxe4 Nxd5

An interesting position! For the piece, Black got only one pawn, but he has full compensation! Excellent judgement! White's pieces are terribly discoordinated while Black has perfect coordination, combining his active pieces with mobile central pawns. In practice, this position is perhaps easier to play with Black.

19.b5!?

White wants to activate his Ba2 as soon as possible. Another logical move was

19.Bb2, developing the bishop and covering c3 - White wants to play Nbd2. Black,

as usual in such situations, pushes his pawns: 19...f5! 20.Re1 (if 20.Rc4, 20...e4

21.Nd4 e3! and now the only move that keeps White in the game is 22.Nd2!) 20...e4

(20...Nf4 is also possible) 21.Nd4 Qg5. analysis diagram White's king has hardly any defenders, while the Ba2, Bb2 and Nb1 are all doing nothing - an excellent example of White's pieces being only 'technically' on the board while Black's pieces are actually playing. White has to be accurate to stay in the game: 22.h4! (22.Ne2 Nxb4 looks bad for White) 22...Qxh4 23.Nxf5 Qg5

24.Ne3 Nf4. Now finally White develops his Nb1: 25.Nc3 (interestingly, even after

the queen trade 25.Qg4 Qxg4 26.Nxg4 Black still has full compensation as White cannot develop, e.g. 26...Nd3 27.Re2 Rec8 28.Na3 d5) 25...d5. Here, best for White is probably 26.Ne2 when Black has a pleasant choice between going for a line ending in perpetual check or just playing for the attack: 26...Nh3+ (the attacking option was 26...Nd3!? 27.Bd4 Bd6) 27.Kf1 Nxf2 28.Kxf2 Bd6. analysis diagram Unfortunately for Black, he is slowly running out of pieces and a draw will probably be the result after 29.Nd4! If White plays 19.Bd2, we have an unclear game after 19...Qf6! (19...f5?! is not precise because the bishop on d2 covers the e3-square and White is better after

The position looks unclear to me. Yes, at the moment Black only has two pawns for the piece, but Black's central pawns are strong, and the bishop pair is good in this type of position... my Stockfish, however, gives a slight plus to White.

24.Nfd2

The alternative was 24.Nbd2 Bg6 25.Bb2 f6 when the position looks unclear to me, my silicon advisor slightly preferring White.

27.Qb3?

Zaitsev dynamics I have decided to conclude this book with a famous game. The diagrammed position shows a principled battle between the two great Ks. Anatoly Karpov loved this structure as Black since it is fundamentally sound while offering Black active play. There is some resemblance with the Benoni, but the pieces are placed differently. Black wants to plant one of his knights on d3, gaining the bishop pair, and often doesn't mind sacrificing a pawn in the process. Black also has the idea of pushing ...f5, hitting White's centre. Black's potential problem? His weak king. Anatoly Karpov was famous for defending his king with a minimum of resources and has done so throughout his matches with Kasparov. I advise the reader to go through their match games while paying attention to this strategy of 'minimum resources' - it will be both interesting and rewarding! Game 47 Garry Kasparov 2740 Anatoly Karpov 2705 London/Leningrad Wch m 1986 In their heritage World Championship matches, the two great Ks battled out a principled 'Zaitsev Variation' fight, and this game is the one I like the most. You may wonder why I included this 'over-analysed' game in my selection... Well, I would like to offer some personal insights and hope they will be beneficial to the reader.

1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5 a6 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.O-O Be7 6.Re1 b5 7.Bb3 d6 8.c3 O-O 9.h3

Bb7 10.d4 Re8 11.Nbd2 Bf8 12.a4 h6 The main line Zaitsev - the battleground of the two great Ks!

13.Bc2 exd4 14.cxd4 Nb4 15.Bb1 c5 16.d5 Nd7 17.Ra3

Over the years, Anatoly Karpov, not only against Kasparov but also in many of his other games, would be choosing here between two principled but strategically rather different options. I like Black's choice in this game, and I think it is enough for equality.

[diagram]
I like Black's ideas here. Black wants to jump ...Nc5 followed by ...Nd3, forcing White to part with his bishop pair. Without his light-squared bishop, White will find it more difficult to build up an attack. Bear in mind, however, that in this game, and often in this line, Black is going to be defending with a minimum of resources! The other principled choice is 17...f5. Black weakens his kingside but wants to eliminate White's pawn centre. The reason why we no longer see this variation at top-level events is the silicon brain's suggestion 18.g4! (Kasparov's choices were

18.Rae3 or 18.exf5). In the few top-level games played with this move, White has

had excellent results. The idea is that 18...fxg4 (to readers willing to invest more time in analysing this position, I would say that in my opinion the positions after

18...f4! are more complicated than the initial computer evaluations tell us) is

answered with 19.Nh2! and White swiftly gets a strong attack. White is now on an important crossroads; he has to chose between three main continuations. I will try to provide some middlegame insight combined with opening information. In this game, Garry attacks Black's pawn on b5 while keeping the option of swinging his Ra3 to the kingside, which is a typical attacking idea in this line.

18.Nd4

A) The alternative, also seen in the K-K matches, is 18.axb5 axb5 19.Nd4. Now Black should eliminate White's attacking rook: 19...Rxa3! (ignoring the danger by playing 19...Qb6 20.Nf5 Ne5 is rather risky as after 21.Rg3! White develops a strong attack, a great example being the game Anand-Adams, San Luis Wch 2005)

20.bxa3 and now is the time for Black to kill White's light-squared bishop: 20...Nd3!

21.Bxd3 cxd3 and the position is about equal. 22.Bb2. Here, modern theory prefers

22...Nc5! (the old classic was 22...Qa5 23.Nf5 Ne5 with complicated play, White

emerging victorious in Kasparov-Karpov, London/Leningrad 1986). In one relatively recent top-level test, White hoped for a kingside attack but it did not materialize and White got in trouble: 23.Re3. The defences of Black's king are limited, but in this game White's attack does not get off the ground: 23...Qa5. White now goes for a sophisticated 'prophylactic attacking move': 24.Kh2 (more straightforward alternatives are 24.Nf5 or 24.Rg3) 24...b4 25.N4b3 Qa4 26.axb4?! (the start of White's problems; he had to opt for 26.Rg3! Nxe4 27.Nxe4 Rxe4

28.Qf3) 26...Qxb4 27.Nxc5 dxc5 28.Qc1 c4 and Black's pawns are strong. Black

was better and went on to win in Huschenbeth-Bu Xiangzhi, Douglas 2019. B) Modern theory follows the silicon brain's suggestions, and top-level games currently feature 18.Ree3!?. The rook runs away from ...Nd3 tempi and is ready to switch to the attacking square g3. We have quite a number of recent top-level games here. The position is very sharp, and probably dynamically balanced. I advise readers interested in theoretical verdicts to investigate in the direction of 18...Nc5! 19.b3 and now: B1) 19...Rc8 leads to White's advantage after 20.axb5 axb5 21.bxc4! (now the Ra3 is fully in play) 21...bxc4 22.Bb2 Nbd3. White now went for a pawn grab with

23.Nxc4 (also promising is 23.Bd4 - White wants to grab the pawn on c4 for free, so

Black has to react: 23...f5 24.exf5 Bxd5 25.f6! and Black is reminded of his potentially weak king) 23...Nxb2 24.Nxb2 g6 25.Na4 Nd7 26.Bd3 and White is a sound pawn up but Black managed to hold a draw in Ivic-Fedoseev, Krasnaya Polyana 2021; B2) Black should sacrifice a pawn with 19...c3! 20.Rxc3, and as a result of the pawn sac, the Ra3 is out of play so Black can open up the position further with 20...f5! with complicated play; Black won in Aravindh-Visakh, Moscow 2020.

18...Qf6 19.N2f3

Karpov now continues his plan to plant the knight on d3:

19...Nc5 20.axb5

A) White has an interesting alternative in 20.Ree3!? with ideas similar to 18.Ree3. We have here an interesting rapid game Anand-Kasimdzhanov played in the final match of a Corsica K.O. event: 20...Nbd3. A1) Here, White had an interesting option in 21.Bxd3 and if 21...b4 (Black has alternatives in 21...cxd3 or 21...Nxd3), White sacrifices an exchange with 22.Bc2! bxa3 23.bxa3. Now Black has to stop Bb2 with 23...c3 and White has sufficient compensation, we have an unclear game after 24.a5 or 24.Ne2; A2) In the game, White went for a pawn grab: 21.axb5 axb5 22.Nxb5 Rxa3 23.Nxa3 Rxe4 24.Nxc4. analysis diagram Rustam now went for an interesting tactical idea, taking a risk: 24...Nxf2!? (24...Rxc4 25.Bxd3 Nxd3 26.Rxd3 Qf5) and it paid off as Vishy now blundered:

25.Qe2? (White had to continue with 25.Kxf2 Rxc4 26.b3! when the black rook does

not have any good squares so an exchange sac is needed: 26...Rxc1! 27.Qxc1 Bxd5 and Black has decent compensation, perhaps White has some plus). Now the tactics are working for Black: 25...Nxh3+! 26.gxh3 Qg6+ 27.Kf2 Rxe3! 28.Bxe3 Qxb1 and Black was material up and went on to win in Anand-Kasimdzhanov, Bastia rapid 2006; B) 20.b3 Nbd3 21.Bxd3 Nxd3 leads to satisfactory play for Black. The position is dynamic while the Ra3 still needs yet to be brought into play.

20...axb5 21.Nxb5 Rxa3 22.Nxa3 Ba6

We have a typical situation for this line. White is a pawn up, Black has the bishop pair and will have a strong knight on d3. The evaluation? A dynamic balance. My personal preference? Black. Kasparov improves his rook and moves away from ...Nd3 tempi:

23.Re3

Karpov says: 'The b2-pawn will be mine.' Please note that Black is not concerned about his king safety and will use a minimum of forces to defend his monarch!

23...Rb8

The alternative was 23...Nbd3!?. White understands that his chances are connected to a kingside attack:

24.e5! dxe5 25.Nxe5 Nbd3

A) 25...Ncd3 was the alternative, covering c2; B) 25...Nxd5!? was an interesting tactical option. B1) 26.Qxd5 leads to a forced draw: 26...Rd8 27.Qf3 Qxf3 28.Nxf3 Nb3!. Black gets his piece back and it ends peacefully: 29.Ba2 (hanging on to the piece with

29.Re1 Bb4 30.Rf1? is not a good idea as Black wins after 30...c3 31.bxc3 Bxa3

32.Bxa3 Bxf1) 29...Nxc1 30.Bxc4 Bxa3 31.Bxa6 Bxb2 with a draw;

B2) I guess Karpov did not like 26.Ng4 when the engine shows zeroes, but to a human the position looks dangerous for Black as the defending forces around his king are limited: 26...Qd6! 27.Rg3 Kh8 28.Qc2 Nd3! 29.Nxc4 Bxc4 30.Qxc4 Nxc1

31.Qxc1. Here, Black is active enough to compensate for the pawn deficit: 31...Nf4

32.Re3 Qd4 with a probable draw.

26.Ng4

One of many critical moments in this game! 26.Qc2! was a better move.

26...Qb6!?

Totally unconcerned about his king safety, Karpov moves another piece away from his monarch. He had a strong resource in 26...Qf5! when Black is better! White has a lot of tactics here but none seems to work, e.g. 27.Rf3 (or 27.Rg3 Kh8) 27...Qxd5. analysis diagram The pawn on b2 will fall, and White does not seem able to create enough on the kingside - after all, his Na3 is out of play while his Bb1 is blocked by Black's Nd3: A) 28.Nf6+? does not work due to 28...gxf6 29.Rg3+ Bg7 30.Bxh6 Ne6 and Black wins with 31.Nxc4 (or 31.Rxg7+ Nxg7 32.Qg4 Kf8) 31...Ndf4!; B) 28.Bxh6 loses to 28...Ne4! and now the Bh6 hangs there is no good retreat:

29.Bc1? Bxa3;

C) After 28.Rg3, now the engine is not afraid to lose a pawn on h6: 28...Qe6! (or

28...Ne4! 29.Nxh6+ Kh8 and Black is better; the safe human move 28...Kh8 is fine

but perhaps it promises no more than a draw after 29.Ne3) 29.Nxh6+ Kh8 30.Re3 Qd7 and Black is better; his Nd3 is simply too strong.

27.Rg3 g6 28.Bxh6

Cold blooded Karpov goes for his pawn:

28...Qxb2 29.Qf3!

Again, a critical moment! White obviously has an attack but, also obviously, he will lose at least a piece - his Na3.

29...Nd7

Anatoly brings one defender closer to his king. The first question, however. is: Can Black grab 29...Qxa3 ? The answer is yes! 29...Qxa3! leads to a draw by perpetual check: 30.Nf6+ Kh8 31.Qh5 Rxb1+ 32.Bc1+ (32.Kh2 leads to a draw too:

32...Rh1+! 33.Kxh1 Nxf2+ 34.Kg1! Qxg3 and White has to force perpetual check

with 35.Bg7+ Kxg7 36.Ne8+) 32...Kg7. There is no mate, so White has to agree to a draw: 33.Ne8+ Kg8 34.Nf6+. Most probably Karpov calculated these lines but rejected them, considering that his position should offer him more. Garry now needs to show great attacking skills indeed!

30.Bxf8 Kxf8

White does not have any immediate threats while he is about to lose decisive material. Kasparov now plays the famous 'prophylactic attacking king move':

31.Kh2!!

Now, in crucial lines, the bishop on b1 will not hang with a check! The position is extremely complicated, and objectively dynamically balanced. It's one of those typical positions where the better calculator wins! Karpov goes for material gain, continuing his strategy of 'minimum defensive resources'. In a World Championship match with one of the greatest attackers in history, using such a strategy takes great confidence!

31...Rb3

A) A player concerned about his king safety may play 31...Qd4. Without the Bb1 and Na3 White can't expect his attack to succeed and a draw is a likely outcome, e.g.

32.d6 (or 32.Qe3 Qxe3 33.Nxe3 Nxf2 34.Bxg6 fxg6 35.Rf3+ Ke7 36.Rxf2 c3 when

the play is still sort of dynamic but a draw is likely) 32...N7e5 33.Nxe5 Nxe5

34.Qc3=;

B) The piece grab 31...Qxa3?? is a blunder: 32.Nh6 N7e5 (or 32...f5 33.Rxg6)

33.Qf6! and White wins as 34.Rxg6 is a terrible threat, e.g. 33...Qb2 34.Rxg6 Ke8

35.Rg3 etc.;

C) Trading an attacker, the Ng4, also makes sense: 31...N7e5 32.Nxe5 Qxe5 and we get a drawn ending after 33.Nxc4 Bxc4 34.Bxd3 Bxd3 35.Qxd3 Rd8.

32.Bxd3 cxd3

Bringing the rook closer with 32...Rxd3 leads to a better ending for White: 33.Qf4 Qxa3 34.Nh6 Qe7 35.Rxg6 Qe5 36.Qxe5 Nxe5 37.Rxa6 Rxd5 and White is a pawn up; the c-pawn is dangerous.

32...Rxa3!, taking the 'insignificant' Na3, is not an easy move to make; it leads to

equality after 33.Qf4 Rxd3 34.Qd6+ Kg7. analysis diagram Which piece to collect? 35.Qxd7! (after 35.Qxa6? Rxg3 36.fxg3 c3 the c-pawn is too strong) 35...Rxg3 36.fxg3 Bb7! (36...c3? is not good as Black's king is weak: 37.Qc7 c2 38.Ne5) with a drawn queen ending after 37.Ne3 Qd4 38.Qxb7 Qxe3=.

33.Qf4

33...Qxa3?

The losing mistake! Karpov probably missed White's 37th move.

33...d2! was needed. This is difficult to calculate and the game was also in the time

trouble phase. Black seems to be able to hold! 34.Nh6 Nf6! (34...Qf6? blunders the pride of Black's position after 35.Qxd2!) A) Now 35.Qd6+ looks very temping but does not win: 35...Ke8 36.Qxa6 d1Q!

37.Qc8+ Ke7 38.Qc5+ Kd7 39.Qc6+ Ke7. Now the only way to continue the fight is

[diagram]
analysis diagram And now the cold-blooded 40...Kf8! (Most players will play 40...Qxd6 but after

41.Qxd6+ Kxd6 42.Nc4+ Ke7 43.Nxb2 Rxb2 44.Rf3! Black still needs to work for

the draw) 41.Qc8+ Kg7. Black has a massive material advantage, but his king is defended with a 'minimum of resources': 42.Nf5+ Kh7 43.Qf8. analysis diagram Black stays alive with 43...Ng4+! 44.Rxg4 (44.hxg4 is not a winning attempt as Black has 44...gxf5 45.f3 Rxf3! and the outcome will be a draw after 46.Qxf7+ Qg7

47.Qxg7+ Kxg7 48.Rxf3 fxg4 49.Rg3 Qxd6 50.Nc2 etc.). Luckily for Black, he has

enough material to give! 44...Rxh3+! 45.Kxh3 Qh1+ 46.Kg3 Qe5+ 47.Rf4 g5

48.Qxf7+ Kh8 49.Qf8+ Kh7.

analysis diagram White still has a funny winning attempt here: 50.Qe7+!? Qxe7 51.dxe7 gxf4+

52.Kxf4

analysis diagram Only White can play for a win here, so Black should now secure a funny draw by stalemate with 52...Qxg2 53.e8Q Qg4+ 54.Ke5 Qe4+ or 54.Ke3 Qe2+; B) 35.Rxb3 Qxb3 36.Qxf6 Qxd5. The d-pawn is strong and Black's king is weak:

37.Nxf7 d1Q 38.Nd6+ Kg8 39.Qxg6+ Kf8 40.Qf6+ Kg8.

analysis diagram

41.Nf5! Qxf5 42.Qxf5 Qd6+ 43.Kg1 Qxa3 White will obviously try here for a bit but

the game should end in a draw.

34.Nh6 Qe7 35.Rxg6 Qe5

The defensive resource Karpov was banking on - White's queen is pinned!

36.Rg8+ Ke7

And now comes the famous move that destroys Black's coordination!

37.d6+!

Black will now first lose his queen, and then some.

37...Ke6 38.Re8+ Kd5 39.Rxe5+ Nxe5 40.d7 Rb8 41.Nxf7 1-0

Show in Text Mode Chapter 7 Exercises Exercise 1 - easy Black to move How should Black proceed? What is the right plan for Black here? Show/Hide Solution Solution 1 Answer: Black first needs to fix the central pawn structure, gain space, and remove White's Bd3 from its good post:

12...c4! 13.Be2

Now, activating the bishop on c8 is the right answer. Korchnoi (in his game vs Mecking, Beverwijk 1978) did it in the most precise way:

13...Qa5 14.Bd2 Bd7

Black has a clear plan (improving his bishop) and is at least equal. [diagram]
and is better as after

(in case of 13.exf6 Nxf6, Black develops fast and takes the initiative)

the kingside is fixed and White's bishop pair is useless, while Black has the advantage on the queenside. Exercise 3 - easy White to move Black has already castled and arguably has a development advantage. He wants to open up the centre with the standard push ...f6. 11.f4!

17...Rhg8 18.h3

45...f5! 46.Bxf5 Ra8

Luckily for White, his piece blunder was not fatal and he escapes into a drawn ending:

With a theoretically drawn ending, though a number of mistakes were still made before White eventually saved a draw in Kasparov-Kramnik, Moscow 2001. It is very good if one of your three candidate moves was the thematic exchange sacrifice:

14.Rb4! Nxb4 15.axb4

21.gxh3!

Black has many tactical ideas that don't work, White has a large advantage here. In the actual game (Agrest-Nisipeanu, Batumi Ech-tt 1999) White reacted with

21.g3?. Now Black's pawn will stay on h3 until the end of the game and due to the

weakness of White's king Nisipeanu managed to save the game: 21...axb5 22.cxb5. Putting his queen on c7 was not a good idea for Black in the first place. 22...Qd8!. White now creates a strong passer on c6 and may have thought he had a winning advantage... 23.Bxe5 dxe5 24.Qxd8 Rexd8 25.Nc6 Bxc6 26.bxc6 ... but Black saves the game due to White's weak king - the pawn on h3 doing an excellent job:

25.Bxh7+! Kxh7 26.Qh5+ Kg8 27.Bxg7!

Exercise 12 - advanced Black to move Black has a typical powerful Rauzer attack. However, he has sacrificed a piece. White's Rh3 and Ng3 are out of play but this may quickly change. 30...b3! 31.Bxb3 Qa3 32.Kc2 Qb2+ 33.Kd3

33...Ba5! 34.Bc4 Rxc4! 35.Ne2
